questions.text: You were studying anatomy for the upcoming exam. Meanwhile your friend asked you this, ''In oogenesis, which of the following events occur immediately following the completion of meiosis II?''

choices.text: Sperm penetration of the corona radiata

questions.solution:
• The secondary oocytes stop in the metaphase of meiosis II and remain in this meiotic stage until fertilization.
  • After fertilization, the secondary egg cell completes meiosis II and forms a mature ovum and a polar body.
  • The nucleus of the mature egg cell is called the female pronucleus, which fuses with the male pronucleus to form a zygote.

questions.text:
Your anatomy lecturer is currently teaching about the Upper limb. He mentions that the simple mnemonic for carpal bones is as follows:- "She looks too pretty, try to catch her."

And then asks which bone has no role in the formation of the wrist joint.

Which of the following would you pick?
questions.solution:
Ulnar bone does not participate in the formation of the wrist joint.

Wrist joint formed by: -

Upper: -

  • Inferior surface of lower end of radius
  • Articular disc of the inferior radioulnar joint

Lower:

  • Scaphoid
  • Lunate
  • Triquetral (ulnar deviation)

questions.text: When does a secondary oocyte complete its second meiotic division to become a mature ovum?
questions.solution:
• Secondary oocyte completes its second meiotic division to become a mature ovum at fertilization.
  • At ovulation, a secondary oocyte begins meiosis II, but this division is arrested at the metaphase.
  • The secondary oocyte will remain arrested in the  metaphase until a sperm penetrates it at fertilization.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the secondary oocyte degenerates.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male suddenly collapses in the middle of the road. You being a doctor rushing to duty, see the patient, stop the car to go and help. You are unable to hear the heartbeat. Sternum or chest bone is where you place your hand to give chest compressions until further help arrives/the patient is shifted to the hospital. The sternum has an attachment to the scapula present posteriorly, via which of the following structures?
questions.solution: • Sternum or chest bone is attached to scapula which is present on the posterior surface with help of clavicle or collar bone so that weight of upper limb is transmitted to axial skeleton via scapula, Clavicle, and sternum

questions.text: A 43-year-old hockey player is hit in the head by a puck. His radiogram shows a fracture of the foramen rotundum. Which of the following nerves would be damaged by this event?
questions.solution:
• Foramen rotundum transmits maxillary nerve .
  • So, injury to the axillary nerve can be expected.

questions.text: In a freak hunting accident, a 17-year-old boy was shot with an arrow that penetrated his Suboccipital Triangle, injuring the Suboccipital Nerve between the Vertebral Artery and the Posterior Arch of the Atlas. Which of the following muscles would not be affected by such a Lesion?
questions.solution:
• The splenius capitis is innervated by the dorsal primary rami of the middle and lower cervical nerves.
  • The suboccipital nerve (dorsal primary ramus of the C1) supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including the posterior major, rectus capitis, obliquus capitis superior and inferior, and the semispinalis capitis.

Note

  • Rectus capitis posterior minor remains intact because it is not associated with C2 vertebrae fracture

questions.text: A 43-year-old female came in with complaints of bipedal edema and abdominal pain for the past few weeks. On further probing, the patient added that she had early satiety and recently lost significant weight. Alarmed, you send for CT, which reveals a retroperitoneal mass compressing the IVC, obstructing it. Which of the following is not involved in collateral supply in such cases?

choices.text: Superior epigastric and inferior epigastric vein

questions.solution:
• In IVC obstruction, collaterals open up to drain blood into SVC and then to the heart (right atrium).
  • Since superficial epigastric and iliolumbar veins both drain into IVC, they are not helping the cause.
  • Superior epigastric and inferior epigastric form collateral in the rectus sheath.
  • Superior epigastric drain into internal thoracic then into SVC which open into the right atrium, hence blood can be drained from IVC into SVC.
  • Superficial Epigastric vein forms collaterals with Lateral Thoracic vein via thoracoepigastric vein in case of either IVC or SVC obstruction

questions.text: A joint capsule or articulate capsule is an envelope surrounding the synovial joint. It is usually made of two layers- an outer fibrous and an inner synovial membrane. Which of the following structures is extracapsular?
questions.solution: Lateral and medial epicondyles are outside the capsular ligament. They are traction epiphysis.

questions.text: A newborn baby was referred to the Pediatric emergency with complaints of difficulty of breathing, incessant crying, and a barrel-shaped chest. X-Ray done revealed a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. As surgery is a must, you would explain to the parents that this condition may result from failure of the:-

choices.text: Pleuroperitoneal membranes to fuse in a normal fashion
Dorsal mesentery of the esophagus to develop

questions.solution:
• The formation of the diaphragm occurs through the fusion of tissue from four different sources. The pleuroperitoneal membranes normally fuse with the three other components during week 6 of development.
  • Abnormal development or fusion of one or both of the pleuroperitoneal membranes causes a patent opening between the thorax and abdomen through which abdominal viscera may herniate.

Fig - development of the diaphragm

questions.text: A man 65 years old presented with the sudden onset of neck pain radiating to the forearm. He had been feeling a dull pain in the left upper back since playing golf two days earlier. You being orthopedician, order an MRI, that reveals a mass involving the cervical nerve root. Which of the following might be affected, if the nerve root affected was C8?
questions.solution:
C8 nerve root supplies -
1. Wrist (and Finger) flexors and
2. Small muscles of the hand

Note: Small muscles of the hand are supplied by C8; T1, More precisely T1.

  • Supinators - C6
  • Wrist (and Finger) extensors—C6(7)
  • Wrist (and Finger) flexors—C7(8)
  • Intrinsic muscles of hand—C8; T1

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to a local hospital for surgery of uterine cancer . As the uterine artery passes from the internal iliac artery to the uterus, which of the following structure crossing inferior to it is sometimes mistakenly ligated during such surgery ?
questions.solution:
• The ureter runs under the uterine artery near the cervix; thus, the ureter is sometimes mistakenly ligated during pelvic surgery.
  • The other structures mentioned are not closely related to the uterine artery near the uterine cervix.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient comes into your clinic with left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder for the past 2 hours. ECG reveals STEMI and you immediately refer a patient to a higher center. The consultant seeks access through the femoral triangle for angioplasty and knows all the following structures pass through it, except:-
questions.solution:
• The Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes are found deep in Camper’s fascia and Superficial to Fascia Lata.
  • Femoral Triangle is a sub-fascial space (fascia lata being the roof), it contains only the Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes

Femoral triangle-

Lateral border: medial border of the sartorius muscle

Medial border: medial border of adductor longus muscle

Base or superior border: inguinal ligament

Contents- Femoral nerve, femoral artery, femoral vein, the femoral canal (space), lymphatics (Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes)

questions.text: A primary active transport occurs in the absence of or against the existing electrochemical gradient and is powered by metabolic energy, such as that originated by the exergonic hydrolysis of ATP. All of the following are examples of primary active transport, except?

choices.text: The Na+/K+ ATPase in the red cell membrane
The H+/K+ ATPase in the parietal cell of the stomach

questions.solution:
• Sodium/glucose symporter is an example of secondary active transport.
  • Sodium-glucose co-transporter (SGLT) mediates apical sodium and glucose transport across cell membranes.
  • Cotransport is driven by active sodium extrusion by the basolateral sodium/potassium-ATPase, thus facilitating glucose uptake against an intracellular up-hill gradient, so-called secondary active transport.
  • They belong to SLC family 5 (Solute Carrier Family)
  • Rest 3 are examples of primary active transport.

SERCA:

  • Sarco Endoplasmic Reticulum Ca++ ATPase (110kDa transport membrane protein).
  • It transports two molecules of Ca++ for each molecule of ATP hydrolyzed.
  • Ca++ pumped out of the sarcoplasm, into the longitudinal tubules, to decrease the sarcoplasmic [Ca++] and thus cause muscle relaxation.

questions.text: Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4) with HCN4 being widely expressed in the SA node. It has also been dubbed an “f” channel and the current produced as funny current. Which of the following is a function of these channels?
questions.solution:
• HCN channel is a Na+ channel (permeable to both Na+ and K+ ions, with increased permeability to Na+), consists of four either identical or non-identical subunits that are integrally embedded in the cell membranes of SA nodal cells to create an ion-conducting pore.
  • Also referred to as “h” channel (activated following hyperpolarization) and the current through the h channels is called “h” current (Ih), and because of its unusual (funny) activation, it has also been dubbed an “f” channel and the current produced as funny current.
  • A major contributor to pacemaker potential.
  • It is a type of metabotropic receptor associated channel activated by cyclic nucleotides (cAMP/cGMP) and more the hyperpolarization, more the activation of the channel.
  • HCN channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4) with HCN4 are widely expressed in the SA node.

questions.text: Calcium-binding proteins are proteins that participate in calcium cell signalling pathways by binding to Ca2+, which plays an important role in many cellular processes. Which of the following is not a calcium-binding protein?
questions.solution:
Clathrin (does not bind ca2+)

  • On inside of cell membrane beneath coated pits, latticework of fibrillar protein is present called clathrin
  • Helps in pinocytosis

Calbindin

  • Present in brush border of intestinal epithelial cells & transports Ca+2 into cell cytoplasm
  • Amount of calcium absorption is directly proportional to the quantity of calcium-binding proteins

Troponin:

  • Troponin C – binds to Ca+2 ions = Strong affinity of troponin to calcium initiate contraction process.

Calmodulin

  • In place of troponin, smooth muscles have calmodulin
  • Ca+2 inside the cell binds reversibly with calmodulin & activates myosin light chain kinase resulting in a chain of events that cause muscle contraction

questions.text: A tetanic contraction is a sustained muscle contraction evoked when the motor nerve that innervates a skeletal muscle emits action potentials at a very high rate. During this state, a motor unit has been maximally stimulated by its motor neuron and remains that way for some time. Tetanizing stimulation of the muscle causes a sustained forceful contraction due to?

choices.text: Failure of Ca++ removal from the sarcoplasm

questions.solution:
• If the frequency of stimulation is increased, the individual twitches occur together (fuse) and cause the muscle tension to remain at a steady plateau state, in which the individual twitches are no longer distinguishable from each other is referred to as tetanus.
  • Tetanizing stimulus (high-frequency stimulation) - stimuli are applied in quick succession, there is a release of Ca++, with each stimulus, from the SR into the sarcoplasm.
  • For the muscle to relax, this Ca++ should be pumped back into the SR, which fails to happen due to the rapid succession of stimuli. The muscle remains in a sustained state of contraction, called “tetanus” (option-2).
  • Recruitment (option-1) - A simple means of increasing the force of contraction of a muscle is to recruit more muscle fibers. Because all the muscle fibers within a motor unit are activated simultaneously, a muscle recruits more muscle fibers by recruiting more motor units.
  • Summation means adding together the individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction (option-3).
  • Beneficial effect: The amount of tension is increasing due to an increase in the amount of Ca++ as the Ca++released by the previous stimulus itself is not cleared and still, Ca++continues to release due to subsequent stimuli (option-4).

questions.text: In men the average hemoglobin content of the blood is 16 g/dL, while women have 14 g/dL. Glycine and succinyl-CoA are the substances from which the heme portion of the hemoglobin molecule is synthesized. Hemoglobin estimation is done by all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Some methods of hemoglobin estimation are :

  • Drabkin’s method
  • Sahli’s method
  • Hemoglobincyanide (HiCN) Method
  • Blood Gas Analyzer (BGA)

Whereas Wintrobe’s method and Westergren’s method are for ESR determination.

questions.text: To regulate gastric emptying, the antrum, pylorus, and upper duodenum apparently function as a unit. Among the following, one does not help in decreasing gastric emptying, identify?
questions.solution:
• Acidity of the chyme, hyper- or hypo-osmolarity of the duodenal contents, irritation of the duodenal mucosa, and protein or fat breakdown products in the duodenum are the factors sensed by the duodenal receptors.
  • Gastric emptying will then be decreased, by a combination of neural and hormonal signals.
  • Neural signals would be enterogastric reflexes in the ENS; they are triggered by the acidic chyme in the duodenum.
  • Hormonal signals would be in the form of CCK, Secretin, G.I.P. released from duodenal mucosa.
  • Fat in the duodenum is a very potent inhibitor of gastric emptying; it causes CCK release.
  • Hormonal factors decrease the gastric motility and cause constriction of the pyloric sphincter. Other effects include: fundic relaxation, inhibition of antral motor activity.
  • Gastrin, in physiological amounts, is known to increase gastric motility.

questions.text: The second heart sound (S2) is a short burst of auditory vibrations of varying intensity, frequency, quality, and duration. It has 2 audible components, the aortic closure sound (A2) and the pulmonic closure sound (P2), which are normally split on inspiration and virtually single on expiration. S2 is produced in part by hemodynamic events immediately following the closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves. S2 occurs during?
questions.solution:
• As the ventricular diastole starts, ventricular pressure begins to fall.
  • Blood ejected out during systole starts flowing back toward ventricles, due to the falling ventricular pressure.
  • This sudden change in the direction of blood marks the phase of protodiastole.
  • Closure of semilunar valves stops this regurgitation of blood toward ventricles. This closure of semilunar valves produces (option-1) S2.
  • Thus, S2 indicates end of the protodiastole, and hence S2 is said to occur in protodiastole. After S2, the isovolumic relaxation starts.

Sound

  

Associated Events

S1

First heart sound (sounds like lub)

Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves
 

Two bursts, a mitral M1 and a tricuspid T1 component

  

S2

Second heart sound (Sounds like dub)

Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
 

An aortic A2 and a pulmonary P2 component

  

OS

Opening Snap

Opening of a stenotic mitral valve

S3

Third heat sound

Diastolic filling gallop or ventricular or protodiastolic gallop

S4

Fourth heart sound

Atrial sound that creates an atrial or presystolic gallop

questions.text: The basal O2 consumption of the arrested heart is approximately 20% that of the contracting heart. The O2 costs for “pressure work” seem to be much higher than “flow work”. O2 consumption by the heart is determined primarily by?
questions.solution:
• The following components determines the O2 consumption by the heart primarily
    • The heart rate,
    • The Contractile state of the myo­cardium, and
    • Intramyocardial tension.
  • Ventricular work per beat corre­lates with O2 consumption

NOTE: O2 consumption by the myocardium is about 2 mL/100 g/min. This value is considerably higher than that of resting skeletal muscle. At rest the O2 consumption by beating heart is around 9 mL/100 g/mins.

questions.text: Diffusion capacity assesses how well a tracer gas in inspired air can cross from the air into the blood. The test measures the absorption of a low concentration of one of the following gases in inhaled air by hemoglobin in red blood cells that circulate through pulmonary capillaries. The gas that is used to measure diffusing capacity of the lung is?
questions.solution:
• Carbon monoxide (CO) is used to measure diffusing capacity of the lung.
  • CO is a ‘diffusion-limited’ gas.
  • CO has high solubility in blood. However, when CO is given by inhalation, it does not remain in aqueous phase. Reason: CO has very high affinity for Hb; it enters red cells and combines with Hb.
  • Due to this, CO content of blood will be high but partial pressure of CO (pCO) will not rise. (Partial pressure is exerted by the gas in solution and not by the gas that combines with Hb).
  • Partial pressure of CO in capillary blood remains close to zero.
  • Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO) at rest = 25 ml/min/mm Hg.

questions.text: 35-year-old male, a known case of Interstitial lung disease. All of the following pulmonary function abnormalities are seen in this patient, except?
questions.solution:
• Interstitial lung disease is a restrictive lung disease.
  • In restrictive lung disease, lung compliance or expansibility is decreased. Hence, vital capacity is reduced.
  • Total lung capacity will also decrease. The diffusion capacity of the respiratory membrane is reduced as the diffusion distance is increased in interstitial lung disease.
  • Since VC is reduced, FEV1/FVC ratio is increased.

questions.text: The kidney plays key roles in extracellular fluid pH homeostasis by reclaiming bicarbonate (HCO3−) filtered at the glomerulus and generating the consumed HCO3− by secreting protons (H+) into the urine (renal acidification). Sodium-proton exchangers (NHEs) are ubiquitous transmembrane proteins mediating the counter transport of Na+ and H+ across lipid bilayers. Which one of the following cells are responsible for acid secretion in the kidney?
questions.solution:
The epithelium of the collecting ducts is made up of principal cells (P cells) and Intercalated cells (I cells).

  • P cells are involved in Na+ reabsorption and ADH-stimulated water reabsorption.
  • Intercalated cells or I cells are of two types: α and β:
    • α-intercalated cells are involved in acid secretion. These cells have an H+-ATPase and an H+-K+-ATPase in their luminal cell membrane and a Cl-/HCO3- exchanger (anion exchanger AE-1) in their basolateral membrane. These cells would cause reabsorption of K+ and secretion of H+; HCO3- is reabsorbed by these cells
    • β-intercalated cells secrete HCO3-; they have H+-ATPase in the basolateral membrane and the Cl-/HCO3- antiporter in the apical membrane.

questions.text: Conversely, an increase in GFR causes an increase in the reabsorption of solutes, and consequently of water, primarily in the proximal tubule, so that in general the percentage of the solute reabsorbed is held constant. This process is called glomerulotubular balance, and it is particularly prominent for Na+. The factor/mechanism involved in glomerulotubular balance is?

choices.text: Sluggish blood flow in medullary interstitium

questions.solution:
• G-T balance refers to the mechanism by which increase in GFR and filtration of Na+ proportionately increases the Na+ (and water) reabsorption. Thus, a constant fraction (67%) of the filtered Na+ and water is reabsorbed from PCT, despite fluctuations in GFR.

Mechanism: [Starling’s forces] ~

  • Increased GFR (and increased filtered load of Na+& water) leading to increased protein concentration in the glomerular capillary plasma (as the fluid has been filtered out of this plasma)
  • Protein-rich plasma leaves the glomerular capillaries via efferent arterioles and enters the peritubular capillaries
  • Colloid Oncotic pressure will increase in peritubular capillaries and will lead to an increase in the solute and water reabsorption by the PCT.

 

Options A & C are involved in tubuloglomerular feedback.

Sluggish blood flow in medullary interstitium is the basis for countercurrent exchange by vasa recta.

questions.text: Biological dehydrogenation reactions are enzyme-catalyzed oxidation-reduction reactions where one molecule losses hydrogen or electrons and the other molecule accept it. Most of the time the cofactor of the enzyme plays a role as an electron acceptor or donor. Which vitamin as a coenzyme is required for glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase?
questions.solution:
Niacin - pyridine derivative.

Coenzyme forms – NADP+, NAD+

  • The coenzymes NAD+ and NADP+ are involved in a variety of oxidation-reduction reactions
  • Selected example of NAD+ & NADP+ dependent enzyme

Enzyme

Coenzyme

Isocitrate dehydrogenase

NAD+

α- Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

NAD+

Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase

NADP+

Malate dehydrogenase

NAD+

Glutamate dehydrogenase

NAD+

Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase

NAD+ or NADP+

Lactate dehydrogenase

NAD+

Alcohol dehydrogenase

NAD+

questions.text: A 15-year-old type I diabetic faints after injecting himself with insulin. He is administered Glucagon and rapidly recovers consciousness. This is best explained by induction of the activity of which of the following enzyme by Glucagon?
questions.solution:
• Glucagon (catabolic hormone) activates the Rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis (catabolic pathway) i.e. Glycogen phosphorylase.

The mechanism is as shown in the figure below:

Figure: Regulation of glycogen metabolism in catabolic (fasting) state

As the glucose is rapidly released by glucagon injection and utilized by brain cells, the patient will recover and regain consciousness.

questions.text: A child’s developmental progress stopped at 2 years and he also developed coarse facial features. Skeletal deformities started to appear over the next year. Laboratory examination showed glycosaminoglycans in the child’s urine. All are functions of Glycosaminoglycans EXCEPT-the
questions.solution:
Role of GAGs

  • lubrication,
  • cushioning effect in tissues,
  • wound healing,
  • anticoagulation,
  • cell adhesion and
  • transparency of cornea.

Transport of lipids in blood is done by lipoproteins e.g. VLDL, LDL

questions.text: Chitin is a homopolysaccharide present abundantly in the exoskeleton of insects and the cell wall of fungi. Which of the following is a component of Chitin?
questions.solution:
• Homopolysaccharide made up of N-Acetyl Glucosamine connected in β (1 → 4) linkage.

  • Second most abundant polysaccharide in nature (Cellulose is the first most abundant)

questions.text: An obese young woman ingested a banned drug that was once used for weight reduction and she developed a high fever. The drug is known to affect ATP formation in the electron transport chain. What could be that drug?
questions.solution:
• Rotenone is a fish poison. It is not an over-the-counter drug → option d is excluded.
  • Barbiturate poisoning leads to hypothermia, not fever → option a is excluded.
  • Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of complex II (succinate dehydrogenase) → option b is excluded.
  • 2,4 dinitrophenol
    • Ionophore which allows proton to pass through & dissipates the electrochemical gradient generated by proton pumps.
    • Uncouples the oxidation from phosphorylation. i.e. Oxidation continues without phosphorylation.
    • So, Energy of electrons is dissipated as heat (raise body temperature)
    • All ionophores are uncouplers of oxidative phosphorylation.
    • It was once used for weight reduction but discontinued later because of adverse effects.

questions.text: TCA is an amphibolic pathway with many of its intermediates being part of other catabolic and anabolic reactions. All of the following are intermediates of the TCA cycle, except:
questions.solution:
Malonate is not an intermediate of the TCA cycle

Malonate

Malate

competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase

intermediate in the TCA cycle.

 

  • TCA cycle intermediates are
    • Citrate,
    • Isocitrate,
    • α-ketoglutarate,
    • succinyl-CoA,
    • Succinate,
    • Fumarate,
    • Malate,
    • oxaloacetate.
  • Acetyl-CoA is completely oxidised
  • Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: A hypercholesterolemia patient taking statin medication complains of muscle soreness and aches. Test of plasma enzymes showed high levels of CK (creatine kinase) particularly CK-MM isoenzyme, a well-known side effect of statin therapy. Which one of the following best describes CK-MM?
questions.solution:
CK-MM is a muscle tissue-specific isoenzyme of CK. It’s a homodimer made of two M subunits.

Muscle produces the M form, brain the B form, and heart both, leading to an MB form (a heterodimer).

High levels of plasma CK-MM will indicate skeletal muscle damage (CK-MM) while any heart-specific damage will release elevated levels of CK-MB in the blood.

Isoenzyme

Subunit

Location

CK-1

BB

Brain

CK-2

MB

Heart (Raised in MI)

CK-3

MM

Muscles

questions.text: A 60-year-old man had a myocardial infarction 8 hours ago. Measurement of which of the following pair of enzymes in plasma will be highly relevant for diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to the table below, CK-MB and AST will be released in the first 8 hours and will be most important for diagnosis. LDH will be raised after 8 hours so its levels will be low at 8-hour time period.

Enzymes raised in MI

CK - 2 / CK - MB

4 - 6 hrs

AST / SGOT

6 - 8 hrs

LDH - 1

8 - 10 hrs

Proteins raised in MI

Myoglobin

2 - 6 hrs (earliest marker, but nonspecific)

Troponin T & I

3 - 6 hrs

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was admitted to the ER with a large amount of blood and protein in his urine. He also has misshaped lenses (anterior lenticonus) and sensorineural hearing loss in his teenage years. The physician suspected it to be a case of Alport syndrome and ordered a genetic test. The tests would most likely show a defect in which of the proteins?
questions.solution:
• In Alport syndrome, there is a defect in type IV collagen that changes the composition of the basement membrane kidney glomeruli.
  • Due to the absence of a function basement membrane, the kidneys are unable in properly filtering waste products from the blood and both proteins and blood can enter the urine.
  • Type IV collagen is also found in the inner ear so it is important for hearing and for the eye.
  • A mutation in α1-antitrypsin will lead to emphysema, mutations in fibrillin lead to Marfan syndrome, and mutations in β-myosin heavy chain can lead to FHC (Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy experienced episodes, where he develops patches of skin rashes that go away in a week to 10 days. A pediatrician told the boy’s parents to give him niacin the next time this will occur, along with a high-protein diet. The rash resolved in a day or two when they did this. This child has which one of the following diseases based on this information?
questions.solution:
Hartnup’s disease (also known as "pellagra-like dermatosis" or "Hartnup disorder") is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting the absorption & reabsorption of nonpolar amino acids (particularly tryptophan). Tryptophan is used to synthesize serotonin, melatonin, and niacin. The deficiency of niacin leads to pellagra.

Cystinuria is a different transport defect, which affects dibasic amino acid transporter.

Ornithine translocase deficiency, also called hyperornithinemia-hyperammonemia-homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive, urea cycle transporter defect, which causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.

Alkaptonuria is due to a defect in homogentisic acid oxidase.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male athlete who is practicing for his upcoming marathon felt chest discomfort during his practice which was relieved after a few minutes of rest. Which of the following is false regarding the cell injury in this scenario?

choices.text: Detachment of ribosomes from the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)
Accumulation of myelin figures in the cytoplasm

questions.solution:
·Small transparent vacuoles can be seen inside the cytoplasm of reversibly wounded cells, and these reflect swollen and pinched-off regions of the ER. This type of non-fatal injury is sometimes referred to as  “Vacuolar degeneration” or “hydropic change”·

·Electron microscopy reveals the ultrastructural alterations of reversible cell damage consist of the following:

  • Changes in the plasma membrane, such as blebs, blunting and loss of polarity
  • Microvilli
  • Mitochondrial alterations such as swelling and the development of tiny white spots
  • Accumulation of “Myelin figures” in the cytosol composed of phospholipids derived from damaged cellular membranes
  • Dilatation of the ER, with a detachment of polysomes
  • Nuclear alterations  with disaggregation of granular and fibrillar elements

Phenomena that consistently characterize irreversible cell injury:

  • inability to reverse mitochondrial dysfunction (lack of oxidative phosphorylation and ATP generation) even after resolution of the original injury
  • profound disturbances in membrane function (breakdown of plasma membrane).

questions.text: A 9 Year old boy, while riding a bicycle was hit by a four-wheeler and suffered generalized abrasions over both lower limbs, rushed to a nearby hospital Inj. Tetanus Toxoid was administered,  wound cleaning and dressing were done. All of the following is false regarding the given Pathology except:

choices.text: Chemical mediators such as histamine play a role in delayed vascular leakage.
Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules.
Transcytosis is not a contributing factor to vascular leakage.
In most cases, vascular leakage starts several hours after injury.

questions.solution:
• Several mechanisms are held responsible for the increased permeability of postcapillary venules( hallmark of acute inflammation).
  • Chemical mediators such as histamine, bradykinin  and leukotrienes, produce endothelial cell contraction which is the immediate transient response.
  • This results in increased inter endothelial spaces - the common mechanism of vascular leakage.
  • In most cases, leakage starts immediately after injury and  sustained for several hours until the damaged vessels are repaired.
  • Increased transport of fluids and proteins through the endothelial cell, called Transcytosis, also contributes to the vascular leakage.

questions.text: You are an Intern in OBG Department, you receive a case of Term Teenage Pregnancy in labor with CephaloPelvic Disproportion. Your Resident doctor instructs you to get the blood investigations done ready as the patient is to be taken for an Emergency LSCS procedure, especially the resident asked u to get the Blood Grouping and Rh typing done first. Which of the following potentially represents the most dangerous situation?
questions.solution:
• Rh-ve mother with 2nd Rh+ve child can result in the development of Hemolytic disease of newborn or  “Erythroblastosis fetalis”. So, it is a dangerous condition.

In hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis), there is an antigenic difference between the mother and the fetus. IgG anti-erythrocyte antibodies from the mother cross the placenta and cause destruction of fetal red cells.

  • This condition is a type II hypersensiti02vity reac­tion.
  • This is Not to be confused with Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn which is a coagulation disturbance in the newborns due to vitamin K deficiency. As a consequence of vitamin K deficiency there is an im­paired production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and protein C and S by the liver.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea, on examination has a blind vaginal pouch with the absence of uterus. To confirm the diagnosis, karyotyping is advised, in which phase of the cell cycle it is done?
questions.solution:
Karyotyping

  • The study of chromosomes
  • Procedure : To arrest dividing cells in metaphase with mitotic spindle inhibitors (e.g., N-diacetyl-N-methylcolchicine [Colcemid]) and then to stain  the chromosomes with Geimsa stain.
  • In a metaphase spread, the individual chromosomes take the form of two chromatids connected at the centromere.

questions.text: A histopathological picture of Hemolytic anemia is shown below. Which of the following is associated with an intrinsic defect in the RBC membrane?
questions.solution:
Disorders with an intrinsic defect in the red cell mem­brane are:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Hereditary elliptocytosis  etc

→ Hereditary spherocytosis is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in red cell membrane that render red cells spheroid, less deformable & vulnerable to splenic sequestration & destruction.

questions.text: A lymph node from the neck of a 26-year-old man with b/l cervical lymphadenopathy reveals total effacement of nodal architecture, as well as the characteristic cell shown below at higher magnification. Which of the following additional studies is best suited for  confirmation of diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• The picture shows a prominent Reed-Sternberg cell (RS cell) which is typical of classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • The diagnosis is based on the biopsy findings and can be confirmed by doing immunohistochemical markers on the lymph node biopsy taken.
  • RS cells are positive for CD15, CD30 and negative for CD20, CD45.
  • These cells also show weak positivity for PAX-5.
  • The other tests are not required for confirmation.
  • Immunohistochemistry is best suited for confirmation of diagnosis in cases of Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 30yr female presented with mucosal bleeds on trauma alongwith history of menorrhagia. Partial prothrombin time is elevated. The Ristocetin assay is positive. Which of the following lab finding will also be seen in the given patient based on the diagnosis?

choices.text: Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time
Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time
Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time
Normal platelet count and decreased bleeding time

questions.solution:
Jlv                

Inheritance            Autosomal dominant

Factor deficiency   VWF

Bleeding sites       Mucosal, Skin

Activated PTT      Prolonged

Bleeding Time       Prolonged or normal

Factor VIII          Normal

VWF                       Low

Factor IX              Normal

Platelet defects are of two types- Functional defect and Quantitative defect.

Platelet function defect -

  • Normal platelet count
  • ↑ Bleeding Time
  • Bernard Soulier disease, VWD, Glanzmann's disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a complaint of abdominal pain and history of significant weight loss. Patient had presence of Irish nodes and Sister Mary Joseph nodes. Name the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Sites for spread of gastric cancer most commonly involve the following:

Supraclavicular sentinel lymph node

Virchow node

Periumbilical lymph nodes

Sister Mary Joseph node

Left axillary lymph node

Irish node

The pouch of Douglas

Blumer’s shelf

Ovary

Krukenberg tumor

questions.text: A 24 year-old female presented with history of bouts of cough and respiratory difficulty since 3-4 months. Picture of cytological examination of sputum is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In above image, eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals are seen.
  • The latter are composed of an eosinophilic protein called galectin-10.
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals are seen in allergic reactions (asthma, bronchitis, allergic rhinitis and rhinosinusitis) and parasitic infections such as Ascariasis (parasitic pneumonia).
  • The cardinal symptoms of an asthmatic attack include chest tightness, dyspnea, wheezing, and coughing (with/ without
    sputum production).
  • In Asthma, eosinophils, Curschmann spirals, and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen in the sputum.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman has a lumpectomy following mammography which revealed carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following is a well-known characteristic or important association of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
• A history of breast cancer in first-degree female relatives and diet high in animal fats are important associations of breast cancer.
  • Associations related to excess estrogen stimulation include:-
  1. High-fat diet
  2. Obesity in females
  3. Early menarche
  4. Nulliparity
  • Additional associations are delayed first pregnancy and exogenous estrogen therapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman came with complaints of swallowing difficulties, dysarthria, fluctuating limb muscle weakness, and bilateral eyelid ptosis with incomplete occlusion. the symptoms decreased with rest and sleep. On examination, there was asymmetrical bilateral eyelid ptosis, unequal palpebral fissures with incomplete occlusion, limitation of facial movements and dysphagia. A neostigmine test was done with the improvement of symptoms post-injection. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease described here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and examination findings points out this as a case of Myasthenia gravis.

MYASTHENIA GRAVIS:

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease caused by a defect of neuromuscular transmission due to antibody-mediated attack on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors or muscle-specific tyrosine kinase (MuSK) receptors at the postsynaptic neuromuscular junction.
  • It is characterized by  muscle weakness and fatigability. Myasthenia is improved by acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or immunosuppressants and in selected cases, thymectomy can be performed.
  • Dysphagia and dysarthria are two common symptoms and are due to oropharyngeal muscle involvement. They can be the first symptoms of the disease and sometimes can be misdiagnosed as emotional problems, usually depression

 Post synaptic defect

questions.text: A 67-years-old man on routine laboratory testing as part of health screening offered by his employer and was advised to visit his physician based on initial test results. He hasn't had any severe symptoms (chills, fever), nor has he lost weight, but he has been feeling more weary in recent months. The patient had no personal or family history of cancer and was not taking any drugs at the time. Physical examination is unremarkable. There is no organomegaly or palpable lymphadenopathy on physical examination. Blood workup done - WBC - 14K/µL, Hb - 13.6g/dL, HCT - 41%. Histopathological picture is attached below. Which one of the following leukemia described here that almost never develops after radiation?
questions.solution:
• Most common leukemia in adults in the West
    • Median age at diagnosis is 60 years
    • Absolute lymphocyte count is >5000/microL
    • The tumor cells express the pan B-cell markers CD19 and CD20, as well as CD23 and CD5
    • Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by predominantly small lymphocytes with condensed chromatin, and scanty cytoplasm
    • Variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes are admixed, that often form loose aggregates -'proliferation centers'
    • When present, proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL.
    • The small lymphocytes get disrupted in the process of making peripheral blood smears, producing so-called Smudge cells.
    • Factors that correlate with worse outcome include
      • presence of deletions of 11q and 17p (the latter involving TP53),
      • a lack of somatic hypermutation,
      • the expression of ZAP-70, a protein that augments signals produced by the Ig receptor, and
      • the presence of NOTCH-1 mutations
      • transformation to an aggressive tumour
    • The transformation is usually to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), so-called Richter syndrome (uncommon, seen in approximately 5% to 10% of patients).

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)

    • There is increased incidence of leukemias (acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome) and solid tumors in several organs (e.g., thyroid, breast, and lungs) in survivors of the atomic bombings or people exposed to radiation
    • Manual of clinical pathology writes “Populations exposed to radiation do not have an increased incidence of CLL.”

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with fever, malaise, weight loss, abdominal pain and myalgias. Workup reveals that the patient has Polyarteritis nodosa. Which of the following is associated with this form of vasculitis?
questions.solution:
• Although the significance remains unclear, almost30% of patients with polyarteritis nodosa have serum antibodies against hepatitis B virus.
  • Arsenic is also associated with the development of angiosarcoma.
  • Chlamydia pneumonia has also been implicated in the development of atherosclerosis.
  • HHV-8, KSHV, causes Kaposi sarcoma in individuals who are infected with human immunodeficiency virus.

questions.text: A patient with hematuria, sensory neural hearing loss and anterior lenticonus; associated with mutation in COL4α5 chain. On electron microscopy of renal biopsy, distinctive "basket-weave" appearance of glomerular basement membrane (GBM) seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Alport syndrome (type of hereditary nephritis) has characteristic electron microscopic findings.
  • The GBM shows irregular foci of thickening alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa, often producing a distinctive basket-weave appearance.

Majority of Alport syndrome patients have X-linked disease as a result of mutation of the gene on the X chromosome encoding the α5 chain of type IV collagen (COL4A5). (α3 chain of the type IV collagen of the GBM in Goodpasture disease)

questions.text: A 68-year-old Caucasian man with history of smoking of 25 pack-year , presented with complaints of new-onset dyspnea on exertion in the setting of workplace dust exposure. During the evaluation, he was found to have deficiency of α1-antitrypsin with development of pulmonary emphysema. Workplace spirometric monitoring over 10 years of surveillance for an on-the-job respirator fit program shows a sharp downward slope in forced expiratory volume in 1st second, or FEV1, during his periods of most significant exposure to the dust , which was attenuated after discontinuation of his workplace exposure. α-1 antitrypsin deficiency is associated -
questions.solution:
α1-Antitrypsin deficiency

  • Deficiency of an α1-Antitrypsin (α1-AT) is an autosomal recessive disorder marked by very low levels of serum protease inhibitor (Pi); Its deficiency leads to emphysema and hepatic disease (cholestasis or cirrhosis).

Pathogenesis

  •  α1-AT is synthesized primarily by hepatocytes. The gene is extremely polymorphic with more than 75 isoforms designated alphabetically based on gel migration mobilities; the most common genotype (more than 90% of people) is designated PiMM.
  • Most mutations result in no or only moderate reductions in a1-AT levels and have no clinical manifestations.
  • However, PiZZ homozygotes (the most common disease genotype) have circulating a1-AT levels below 10% of normal.
  • This occurs because PiZ has a single glutamic acid to lysine substitution, resulting in protein misfolding and preventing egress from the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • This triggers the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response, including autophagy, mitochondrial dysfunction, and pro-inflammatory nuclear factor-kB (NF-kB) activation, all causing hepatocyte damage. Additional genetic or environmental factors modify the pathogenesis since only 10% to 15% of PiZZ homozygotes develop overt liver disease.

Morphology

  • α1-AT deficiency is characterized by periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)- positive (diastase-resistant) cytoplasmic globules in periportal hepatocytes.
  • Hepatic manifestations range from cholestasis to hepatitis to cirrhosis.

Clinical Features

  • Neonatal hepatitis with cholestatic jaundice occurs in 10% to 20% of newborns with α1-AT deficiency; later presentation may be attributable to acute hepatitis or complications of cirrhosis. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of PiZZ homozygous adults. Smoking accentuates lung emphysematous damage.
  • Treatment is liver transplantation
  • Autosomal recessive disorder of protein folding marked by very low levels of circulating α1-Antitrypsin (α1AT).
  • Neonatal hepatitis with cholestatic jaundice appears in 10% to 20% of newborns with the deficiency.
  • In adolescence, the presenting symptoms can be related to cirrhosis, hepatitis, or pulmonary disease that is emphysema.

questions.text: On routine examination, it is discovered that a 35-year-old woman had been exposed in-utero to Diethylstilbestrol (DES) administered to her mother, who had a history of recurrent spontaneous abortion. The history given above suggests that the patient might be at increased risk of which of the following?
questions.solution: • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is the risk factor for clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix in young women with a history of in-utero exposure to DES while their mothers were pregnant.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male came in with a complaint of constant right upper back pain. On examination, you find that the pain was 2/5 on the visual analog scale for pain and decide to give medication for the same. If you prefer to give oral medication, which of the following drugs do you think has maximum chances of absorption from gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
• Diclofenac sodium is a weak acid and is  non-ionized in the acidic medium of the stomach.
  • Drugs, when in a similar medium are non-ionized and lipid-soluble. Therefore, Diclofenac sodium has the maximum chance of absorption from the stomach.
  • Other drugs given in the options are weakly basic drugs that are ionized at gastric pH.

Note:

  • Most of the drugs ending with 'ine' are basic like morphine, quinidine, hyoscine, atropine, tubocurarine, etc.
  • Drugs forming salts with cations like sodium or potassium are acidic like diclofenac sodium, thiopentone sodium, etc
  • Drugs forming salts with anions like sulfate, phosphate, etc. are basic like morphine sulfate, chloroquine phosphate, etc

questions.text: A 49-year-old male came into your clinic with complaints of diplopia, slurred speech, difficulty in breathing, drooping of eyelids and generalized fatigue by end of the day. The complaints worsened progressively throughout  the day and the patient comparatively felt better with rest. You suspect Myasthenia gravis as the diagnosis and confirm the same with tests. For cases of MG, you would prefer to give neostigmine over physostigmine because -

choices.text: It has a longer duration of action
It has additional direct agonistic action on nicotinic receptors at the muscle endplate

questions.solution:
• Neostigmine is a quaternary ammonium derivative and is water-soluble.
  • Its absorption from GIT and its penetration in the brain and cornea is much less than physostigmine.
  • It produces additional action on NM receptors.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient came in with symptoms suggestive of Acute CHF. Your senior consultant advised you to give digoxin for the same. You being an overzealous intern, gave an excess dosage of the drug, and the patient suddenly developed ventricular arrhythmia! Which of the following monovalent cation would you give to reverse it?
questions.solution:
• Potassium (K+) is a monovalent cation that can reverse a digitalis-induced arrhythmia.
  • K+ and Digitalis bind on the same receptor on Na+/K+ ATPase.
  • Hyperkalemia decreases Digitalis toxicity (digitalis induced arrhythmia) and Hypokalemia increases Digitalis toxicity.
  • Ca2+ facilitates the toxic actions of cardiac glycosides by accelerating the overloading of intracellular calcium stores that appears to be responsible for digitalis-induced abnormal automaticity.
  • Hypercalcemia, therefore, increases the risk of a digitalis-induced arrhythmia
  • The effects of Mg2+ are opposite to Ca2+. These interactions mandate careful evaluation of serum electrolytes in patients with digitalis-induced arrhythmias.
  • Lignocaine: DOC for digitalis induced arrhythmia
  • Digibind antibodies: Used in severe digitalis toxicity.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male, who is a known case of AIDS is currently undergoing treatment with a regimen that includes Stavudine in it, which of the following is accurate about the drug?

choices.text: It is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor

questions.solution:
• Stavudine is an NRTI that is responsible for maximum peripheral neuropathy.
  • It is a thymidine analogue that acts in the same way as Zidovudine.
  • Because of long-term serious metabolic complications like lipodystrophy, lactic acidosis, and peripheral neuropathy, Stavudine is no longer employed in WHO as well as NACO regimens.

questions.text: You see a 45-year-old male patient, already diagnosed case of Chronic CHF, currently on medications. Even now, you notice that he has difficulty walking short distances. While reviewing medications, you notice that the patient is taking eplerenone, which is:-

choices.text: Able to cause hyperkalemia in predisposed patients

questions.solution:
• Eplerenone is an Aldosterone antagonist  (like Spironolactone).
  • It is used as a potassium-sparing diuretic and can cause hyperkalemia  in susceptible individuals, particularly in patients on ACEIs.

questions.text: A patient is currently in your rural clinic without much infrastructure, for a condition ‘x’ and is unable to swallow food/ medications. Considering the condition ‘x’ may be anything, which one of the following cannot be used since there is no intranasal preparation available?
questions.solution:
• β2 agonists like salbutamol and terbutaline can be administered by the inhalational route.
  • Ipratropium and tiotropium are inhalational anticholinergic agents.
  • Inhalational steroids include Budesonide, Fluticasone, Beclomethasone, and Flunisolide.
  • Theophylline is given by the oral route and is not used by the inhalational route.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female came into your clinic with complaints of irregular periods, infertility, and breast pain. After collecting relevant history, before doing the physical examination, as you suspect and consider hyperprolactinemia as your diagnosis, you ask if the patient is taking any of the following medications, except?
questions.solution:
• Hyperprolactinemia is caused by D2 blockers.
  • All the drugs listed are D2 blockers except Bromocriptine which is a D2 receptor agonist. It is also used in the treatment of Hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male came in with complaints of tremors in the hand. You notice he is unable to take proper stride while walking and on examination, you see there is cogwheel rigidity in the arm. Which of the following antiparkinsonian drugs would you prescribe, that directly activates dopaminergic D2 receptors in the striatum?
questions.solution:
Directly acting D2 receptor agonists can be:

  • Ergot derivatives e.g. bromocriptine and pergolide
  • Non-ergot compounds e.g. pramipexole and ropinirole

questions.text: A patient Amit Kumar is suffering from atherosclerosis. Which of the following is the most beneficial drug for the prevention of stroke in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Antiplatelet drugs are used for the prophylaxis of arterial thrombotic conditions like stroke and MI.
  • Atrial fibrillation increases the risk of thromboembolism and can result in a stroke.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting, and fatty stools. On further questioning, the patient told that he was taking a drug for the past few days. A diagnosis of Biliary sludge syndrome was made. Which of the following is the most likely drug involved?
questions.solution:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside and is excreted via the renal route.

 

BILE secreted anti-microbial agents

CEF in → Cefoperazone, Ceftriaxone

R → Rifampicin

E → Erythromycin

N → Nafcillin

A → Ampicillin

L → Lincosamides (Clindamycin)

DISEASE → Doxycycline

Ceftriaxone can precipitate with calcium, like what occurs with bilirubin, and so ceftriaxone-associated biliary sludge is mainly composed of a calcium-ceftriaxone complex.

questions.text: Roopa Devi, a 65-year-old female with Ovarian cancer is being treated with Cisplatin-based chemotherapy. All of the following are used to limit the toxicity of cisplatin except:
questions.solution:
• N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol poisoning. Some studies suggest it might help prevent contrast-induced nephropathy.
  • Slow intravenous infusion and chloride diuresis along with amifostine can limit cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male comes into your clinic with a 4.5cm long superficial cut wound. You decide to suture it yourself, take consent, and ask the nurse to bring a local anesthetic. Which of the following, though has the longest action, would not be your primary choice as it is the most toxic local anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
• Longest acting, most potent, and most toxic LA is Dibucaine.
  • Chloroprocaine is the shortest acting LA.

questions.text: A patient suffering from cough, sore throat, fever, and chills visited the morning session of the OPD. His sample was sent for culture. The lab technician performed the culture method shown in the figure below. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
Streak culture

  • A streak plate involves the progressive dilution of inoculum of bacteria or yeast over the surface of solidified agar medium in a Petri dish.
  • The result is that some of the colonies on the plate grow well separated from each other. The procedure aims to obtain single isolated pure colonies.

Lawn culture: provides uniform surface growth of bacteria.

It is useful for bacteriophage typing and Antibiotic Sensitivity test.

Stroke culture: It is made in tubes containing agar. It is used for providing a pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination.

Pour plate method: Agar medium is melted and appropriate dilutions of inoculum are added to molten agar and mixed well. Then it is poured into a petri dish and allowed to set and after incubation bacterial colonies will appear throughout the depth of the medium.

This method gives a viable count in a suspension.

questions.text: An 85-year-old male complaining of cough with sputum, fever with chills, shortness of breath, and chest pain. On testing, he was found to be positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae antigens in the urine and exhibited a high fever with shivering. Therefore, his condition was diagnosed as pneumonia. Later, a positive culture of S. pneumoniae in the sputum was also confirmed. Which of the following statement is true regarding Pneumococcus?

choices.text: Virulence is due to polysaccharide capsule
Antibodies against capsule are not protective
Resistance to penicillin has not yet been reported

questions.solution:
True statement regarding Pneumococcus is that Virulence is due to polysaccharide capsule.

  • Capsular polysaccharide (soluble specific substance) is the principal virulence factor→that protects from phagocytosis.
  • Immunity to infection with pneumococci is type-specific and depends on antibodies to the capsular polysaccharides.
  • Vaccines can induce the production of antibodies to capsular polysaccharides which are protective.
  • Pneumococcus has been reported resistant to penicillin due to modification of PBP (Penicillin-binding protein) to PBP2b.
  • Rx- Macrolides are given alternative for penicillin-resistant pneumococci or patients allergic to penicillin.

Pneumococcus:

  • Gram-positive cocci in pairs, lanceolate [flame shaped].
  • capsulated.

 

  • draughtsman/carrom coin-like colonies on various culture media.

  • Quellung reaction - capsular swelling - serological reaction.

B- bile soluble

I -inulin fermenter

O-optochin sensitive

Diseases:

  • conjunctivitis
  • otitis media
  • meningitis
  • pneumonia - typical/lobar pneumonia
  • sinusitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presented to a rural hospital in Ghana with fever, mucopurulent discharge, pain during sex, and generalized malaise. Neisseria gonorrhoeae was isolated from the specimen which was resistant to penicillin, ciprofloxacin, and cotrimoxazole. The virulence factor of this pathogen includes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
The above clinical condition is cervicitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

The virulence factor of Neisseria gonorrhoeae includes all of the following except M protein.

Options 1, 2 and 4

Neisseria gonorrhea:

Gram-negative diplococci, kidney-shaped, mostly noncapsulated.

Virulence Factors of Gonococci:-

  • Pili or fimbriae: Principal virulence factor; helps in adhesion and inhibit phagocytosis.
  • Outer membrane proteins:
    • Porin (protein I): They form membrane channels (pores).
    • Opacity-associated protein (Protein II): It helps in adhesion and invasion.
  • Transferrin-binding and lactoferrin binding protein: It is required for uptake of iron.
  • IgA1 protease: It degrades mucosal IgA antibody.
  • Lipooligosaccharide (LOS): It differs from LPS of Enterobacteriaceae by lacking the repetitive O side chain.

Option 3
  • M protein is a virulence factor of Streptococcus pyogenes, not Gonococci.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with exacerbation of COPD was admitted to the ICU and intubated. He was treated as a case of central venous catheter-related MRSA bacteremia and discharged. He was again admitted to the ER for a dissecting aneurysm of the abdominal aorta which was promptly treated by surgery. The physician suspected a chronic bacterial infection and sent him for a culture examination on nutrient agar. What is the concentration of agar in nutrient agar?
questions.solution:
The concentration of agar in nutrient agar is 2%.

Nutrient agar:

  • Type of Simple/Basal Media
  • Made-up of peptone water + meat extract (1%) + 2% agar.

Properties of agar that makes it an ideal solidifying agent :

  • It can’t be utilized/degraded by bacteria.
  • Melting point → 98oC [autoclavable]
  • solidifying point → 42oC

The concentration of agar:·

  • For solid agar: 1–2% (Japanese agar 2% or New Zealand agar 1.2%)·
  • For semisolid agar: 0.5%·
  • For solid agar to inhibit Proteus swarming: 6%

questions.text: A 35 year man working in a wheat grain godown presented with fever and had axillary lymphadenopathy. The sample was sent to the laboratory to perform Wayson staining for the suspected organism. Reports confirmed plague as the final diagnosis. What is the most likely vector responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Xenopsylla cheopis is the most likely vector responsible for the plague.

Option 2

Xenopsylla cheopis

  • It is the agent of plague, a zoonosis, transmitted from rodents by the rat flea.
  • The natural reservoir for plague is rodents.

Option 1

Vector- Louse (Pediculus humanus corporis)

cause:- Trench fever

Option 3

Ixodid daminii:

The causative agent of Lyme’s disease

Option 4

Haemaphysalis spinigera:

The causative agent of KFD

questions.text: A 30 years old male presented with discrete hypopigmented macules on his upper back, On examination of skin scrapings with 10% KOH under a microscope spaghetti and meatball appearance was seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis Versicolor or Tinea versicolor is a superficial infection of the skin caused by Malassezia furfur (Pityrosporum orbiculare).
  • COLONY → Yeast like consistency
  • CLINICAL FEATURES: presents with discrete hyperpigmented or hypopigmented macules/scales (Refer to the image below)on the chest or upper back.

1. HIGHER incidence in tropics

2. PREDISPOSING FACTORS:

  •  Perspiration
  • Corticosteroids
  • Malnutrition
  • Hereditary
  • Immunosuppression

DIAGNOSIS:

Microscopic Examination of Skin Scrapings:

→ scales + 10% KOH → SPAGHETTI & MEATBALL APPEARANCE (Refer to the image below)

→ scales + Wood lamp → Yellow Fluorescence

→ Scales + SDA & olive oil overlay [Lipophilic fungus] → FRIED EGG COLONIES

Treatment for T. Versicolor:-

  • Topical → Selenium sulfide, salicylic acid, a solution containing sulfur, terbinafine cream.
  • Oral → Ketoconazole.

Answers to other options:

Tinea corporis: Oral terbinafine or itraconazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

The antifungal drugs recommended depends upon the type of candidiasis:

  • Cutaneous candidiasis or oral thrush – drug of choice is a topical azole
  • Esophageal and vulvovaginal candidiasis – drug of choice is oral fluconazole
  • Disseminated candidiasis - drug of choice is Amphotericin B

questions.text: A patient presents with diarrhea and GI disturbance. He complained of foul-smelling fatty stools. Analysis of stool on wet mount shows motile protozoa without RBCs and pus cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is giardiasis.

It results in Malabsorption Syndrome, and Steatorrhoea (Fat in stools, Bulky stools).

  • Predisposing conditions to giardiasis are agammaglobulinemia, common variable immunodeficiency, and selective IgA-deficiency.

Option 1
  • Balantidium coli may cause Dysentery: Ulcers mimic amebic ulcers but never invade the muscular layer.

Option 2

1. Giardia causes noninvasive diarrhea so there will be no RBCs.

2. In acute giardiasis, diarrhea is often foul-smelling with fat and mucus without blood. It causes GI disturbances

3. Microscopy: Demonstration of either trophozoite (active infection) or cyst (carrier) sample by iodine and saline wet mount preparations.

TROPHOZOITE (image above):

  • TENNIS RACQUET APPEARANCE OR MONKEY FACE APPEARANCE OR TEARDROP APPEARANCE
  • Axostyles are present
  • 4 pairs of Flagella → FALLING LEAF LIKE MOTILITY
  • Sucking disc → helps in adherence to various surfaces (Virulence factor)
  • ENTERO TEST/ STRING TEST done to demonstrate Trophozoites.

CYST (image below):

  • 4 nuclei present
  • have Axostyle

Risk factors of Giardiasis:

  • Gammaglobulinemia
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective IgA deficiency.
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Poor hygiene
  • Elderly debilitated persons

Option 3

T. hominis- nonpathogenic, may be associated with diarrhoeagenic stools

Option 4

E. histolytica causes Dysentery (RBCs in stool).

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented to the OPD with RUQ pain and intermittent low-grade fever. Both USG and CT demonstrated a cystic lesion with vesicles at its periphery in segments 6 & 7 of the liver. The patient showed a positive Casoni's test. Which of the following is the intermediate host for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Man is the intermediate host for the given condition.

The clinical scenario is indicative of hydatid disease.

Echinococcus granulosus:

1. Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

2. Definitive host: Dog and wild carnivores.

3. Intermediate hosts: Man and other herbivorous animals.

4. Man is an accidental host (dead end).

5. Eggs: Infective stage of the parasite.

6. Eggs transform into larva (hydatid cyst) that penetrate GIT and migrates to various organs like the liver.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who had a renal transplantation 2 months before developed a fever and came to your clinic for consultation. After a complete evaluation, bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonitis was identified. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent:
questions.solution:
CMV (Cytomegalovirus) is the most likely etiological agent.

Option 1

Herpes simplex:

  • HSV 1 causes mainly oral herpes in the form of Herpes labialis (Refer to the image below)
  • HSV 2 causes genital Herpes.

Option 2

CMV is the most common viral pathogen complicating transplantation.

It most often manifests as pneumonitis in the first four months after transplantation.

It can also cause leukopenia in solid organ transplant recipients, obliterative bronchiolitis in lung transplants, and graft atherosclerosis after heart transplantation.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) also causes:

  • Congenital CMV Syndrome: hepatosplenomegaly, petechial lesions, chorioretinitis, calcification, microcephaly, mental Retardation.
  • Mononucleosis-like syndrome: Atypical lymphocytes [CD8 T cells mainly] and PAUL Bunnel Test negative.
  • CMV Retinitis: CD4 count → <50 cells/mm3

Option 3

EBV (Epstein Barr Virus) causes:

  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Nasopharyngealal carcinoma
  • Burkitt’sts lymphoma
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma / Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Tonsillar carcinoma
  • Duncan syndrome.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia.

Option 4

Varicella-zoster can cause chickenpox in primary exposure and Zoster or Shingles on reactivation of primary lesion in old age >60yrs.

questions.text: A 27-year-old white man presents to his family doctor complaining of being tired all the time and having a slight fever for the past two weeks. He recently returned from a trip to Las Vegas, where he indulged in some of the infamous nightlife. His physical exam is unremarkable except for a macular rash over his trunk and on the palms of his hands. There are no lesions or ulcers on the penis. What organism is causing this man's illness?
questions.solution:
Treponema pallidum is causing this man's illness.

Treponema pallidum:

  • Transmitted through unprotected sexual activity with an infected individual.
  • Presents with the symptoms of secondary syphilis, which includes malaise, mild fever, and rash on the palms and trunk.
  • The primary lesion (chancre) may go unnoticed because it is painless and subsides in a few weeks.

Option 1

Chlamydia trachomatis:

  • Non-gonococcal urethritis
  • serotypes L1, L2, L3: cause lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option 2

Neisseria gonorrhea: urethritis, cervicitis

Option 3

Stages of syphilis:

1:Primary syphilis: Hard painless chancre.

2:Secondary syphilis:

  • Rashes over palms and soles.
  • Condylomata lata.

3: Latent syphilis

4. Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummas (skin lesions)

Complications:

  • Neurosyphilisis :

- Tabes dorsalis/syphilitic myelopathy.

Option 4

Borrelia burgdorferi: Lyme disease

  • It is transmitted to humans through the bite of ticks.
  • Typical symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans.

questions.text: A famous actor allegedly committed suicide by hanging recently. On examination, there was evidence of dribbling of saliva, protrusion of the tongue, and ligature marks around the neck. What type of tissue injury are ligature marks an example of?
questions.solution:
• Ligature mark seen in case of hanging is a typical example of pressure abrasion
  • Pressure abrasions are caused when a relatively less amount of force is applied constantly on an area of the body for a considerable long time.

Causative forces :

  • Pressure abrasion: Ligature mark in hanging & strangulation
  • Scratch abrasion: Fingernails, pin, thorn, the tip of a knife
  • Graze abrasion: Road traffic accidents
  • Patterned abrasion: Tyre marks, Ligature mark.

questions.text: The body of the 28-year-old woman who had allegedly committed suicide by self-immolation was observed by the forensic doctor. There were multiple large splits in the skin on the abdomen and the buttock regions. There was no bleeding in the wounds. How will the margins of these heat ruptures be on observation?
questions.solution:
HEAT RUPTURE HAS IRREGULAR MARGINS WITH NO CONTUSION OR ABRASION

Heat Rupture/splits

  • Due to excessive heat, severe burning/ charring, skin contracts, and ruptures
  • Irregular margins, may resemble lacerations (rarely even incised wounds)
  • Sites: Fleshy areas, Extensor surfaces & joints.
  • Multiple, Large (several centimeters)
  • No Bleeding in the wound
  • Coagulated blood in the vessels (by heat)
  • Intact nerves, and blood vessels in the floor of heat rupture.
  • Vital reaction is absent
  • No bruising/abrasion in the margins

questions.text: A 40-year-old officer has been arrested after being named by a 27-year-old employee for harassment. Among the various charges being registered against him, one offense is charged under IPC 509. What specific offense is he being charged for, under that section?

choices.text: Act intended to insult the modesty

questions.solution:
S. 509 IPC:

  • Whoever intending to insult the modesty of any woman, utters any word, makes any sound or gesture, exhibits any object, or intrudes upon the privacy of such woman
  • simple imprisonment up to 3 years and also fine.

questions.text: The body of the 27-year-old woman has been recovered from the site where it was buried after the suspect confessed to the crime. Autopsy findings suggest that the woman has been physically and sexually assaulted but death has occurred secondary to Traumatic asphyxia. Traumatic asphyxia is a type of?
questions.solution:
• Strangulation/hanging: Occlusion of the internal airways by external pressure over the neck
  • Smothering: caused by closing the external respiratory passages either by the hand or other means
  • Overlaying: due to compression of the chest to prevent breathing; usually occurs when the mother or other person shares a bed with an infant.
  • Traumatic asphyxia: Restriction of chest movement due to external mechanical fixation
  • Choking: caused by an obstruction within the air passages usually between the pharynx and bifurcation of the trachea
  • Gagging: results from forcing a cloth into the nasopharynx
  • Wedging: Occlusion of the internal airways by external pressure
  • Positional asphyxia- Death caused by "Jackknife position''
  • Throttling/ Manual strangulation – compression of neck by human hands
    • Mechanism of death – occlusion of carotids as the carotid arteries lie over the transverse processes of the C4 – C6 Cervical vertebra and any anterolateral impact can compress them against the underlying bone
    • Occlusion of airways plays a minor role and pure asphyxia is rare; considerable pressure is necessary to obstruct the trachea which will also block jugular veins and carotid arteries
  • Spanish windlass technique
    • Strangulation is caused by compression of the neck by a ligature which is quickly tightened by twisting it with a lever (rod, stick, or ruler)
    • It results in a sudden loss of consciousness and collapse
    • Form of garroting Q

questions.text: The forensic team has concluded the autopsy of the 35-year-old clerk who had suddenly collapsed during his night shift. The final report states that it was a Negative autopsy. What does the team mean when using that term?

choices.text: No cause of death is found on gross as well as histopathological examination
Cause is apparent on gross examination but not on histopathological examination
Cause is apparent on gross examination but not found because of constraints on the part of a doctor

questions.solution:
Negative Autopsy:

  • Cause of death could not be ascertained even after complete examination and other tests.
  • 2 – 5 % of all autopsies are negative

# Do not confuse with Defective autopsy: Cause of death could not be ascertained due to incomplete examination, maybe due to lack of training of doctor or inadequate equipment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been accused of rape by his 26-year-old female friend. The woman allegedly was lured by the man on the pretext of helping with an assignment but had later spiked her drink and raped her while she was unconscious. The team has taken swabs of his urethral lining to test for the presence of vaginal cells. The test that would be done for the same is?
questions.solution:
• Lugol’s iodine test is to detect vaginal epithelial cells containing glycogen.
  • Takayama test is to detect bloodstains; while the Florence test is a test for seminal stains.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of fever, chills, cough, and headache. Which of the following study pattern is best for establishing the natural history of disease?
questions.solution:
• The natural history of disease is best established by cohort studies.

COHORT STUDY:

  • Forward-looking study
  • Prospective study
  • Cause to effect study
  • Risk factor to disease study
  • Exposure to outcome study [ hence the natural history of disease is best established ]
  • Follow-up study
  • Incidence study

questions.text: A 23-year-old male working in an iron factory visited the hospital for taking his TT dose. Injectable tetanus toxoid (TT) is an example of which the following immunity?
questions.solution:
• The toxins produced by organisms such as Diptheria & Tetanus are detoxicated and used in the preparation of Vaccines (Toxoids).
  • These detoxified toxins when administered in the body can elicit immune response resulting in antibody production & memory.
  • The Antibodies produced neutralize the toxic moeity produced during infection by these organisms thus providing active immunization to the body.

 

Active Immunity

Passive Immunity

Definition

Include humoral and cellular responses of host

Results in Ab production in the body.

Formed by transfer of ready made antibodies

Host body does not produce its own Ab.

Modes of acquiring

Following clinical infection, subclinical/ inapparent infection or immunization with an Ag.[vaccinations]

Administering Ig / antiserum or transplacental transfer of Ab/ Transfer of lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 55 year old female presented to the hospital with a lump in her breast. On examination there is a presence of dimpling sign. Mammography was performed by the physician. Which of the following is a characteristic of Diagnostic test (as compared to Screening test)?

choices.text: Test results are arbitrary and final
Based on one criterion or cut-off point
Done on those with indications or sick

questions.solution:
Screening test

Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy

Done on those with indications or sick.

Applied to groups

Applied to single patients, all diseases are considered

Test results are arbitrary and final 

Diagnosis is not final but modified in light of new evidence, diagnosis is the sum of all evidence. 

Based on one criterion or cut-off point 

Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs (e.g., diabetes) and laboratory findings.

Less accurate: less expensive: Not a basis for treatment  

More accurate: More expensive: used as a basis for treatment 

The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care  

The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint.

questions.text: Crude birth rate measures the incidence of live births in the total population in a given period of time. Which of the following is not true about Crude Birth Rate?

choices.text: It is a measure of fertility
It is independent of the age structure of the population
Numerator does not include still births

questions.solution:
Crude birth rate -

  • Measure of fertility
  • Measures the incidence of live births in the total population in a given period of time (one year).
  • The numerator is a sub-set of the denominator; so it is a Rate.
  • It is independent of the age structure of the population.

questions.text: A 28 year old pregnant female visited the rural PHC to ask the physician about antenatal visits. How many antenatal visits covering the entire period of pregnancy are minimum required?
questions.solution:
Minimum no. of Antenatal visits required in Pregnancy : 4

  • 1st visit - within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected, for registration of pregnancy and first antenatal check-up.
  • 2nd visit between 14 and 26 weeks POG.
  • 3rd visit - between 28 and 34 weeks POG.
  • 4th visit - between 36 weeks - Delivery

Recommended Antenatal visits: 13-14

  • 0-7 months = once a month = 7 visits
  • 8th month = twice a month = 2 visits
  • 9th month onwards = one visit/ week =4-5 visits

Post natal visits: 3-4

  • 3 in institutional delivery- Day 3,7,42
  • 4 in home delivery- Day 1,3,7,42

questions.text: A 28 year old female recently delivered a healthy baby in the hospital. The physician is consulting her about the importance of breast milk. Which of the following fatty acid is found exclusively in breast milk?
questions.solution:
• Fatty acid found exclusively in breast milk: DHA (Docosa hexanoic acid)[ essential fatty acid]
  • It aids in development of brain by promoting myelination of neurons.

OTHER ESSENTIAL FATTY ACIDS & THEIR RICH SOURCES:

  • Linoleic acid, Arachidonic acid - Safflower oil
  • Linolenic acid - flaxseed oil, soyabean oil
  • Eichosa pentanoic acid - fish oils.
