questions.text: A 30 year old male presented to the OPD with fever, chills, headache, large swollen lymph nodes and fatigue. The condition was diagnosed as plague. Which of the following organism transmits Plague?
questions.solution:
Plague is transmitted through Rat Flea

  • Rat flea transmits [Xynopsylla]: Bubonic plague, Murine typhus, Chiggerosis.
  • Soft tick transmits: Relapsing fever, Q fever, KFD outside India.
  • Hard tick transmits: Tularemia, Tick paralysis, Tick encephalitis, Babesiosis, Tick hemorrhagic fever, KFD in India, congo fever.
  • Mite transmits: Scrub typhus, Scabies.
  • Mosquito transmits: Malaria, Dengue, Yellow fever, Lymphatic filariasis etc.

questions.text: The United Nations International Children Emergency Fund organized a 'GOBI campaign' to encourage 4 strategies for a child health revolution. What does ‘O’ stands for in GOBI?
questions.solution:
• UNICEF - United Nations International Children Emergency Fund]
  • UNICEF is promoting GOBI campaign to encourage 4 strategies for a child health revolution:
    • G: growth charts (to better monitor child development)
    • O: oral rehydration (to treat mild and moderate dehydration)
    • B: breast feeding
    • I: immunization (against TB, polio, diphtheria, Pertussis, tetanus and measles)
  • GOBI campaign is now GOBI-FFF:
    • Family Planning
    • Female education
    • Food supplementation

questions.text: A group of experts discuss a health topic in front of an audience, with no specific order of speeches. This method of communication is?
questions.solution:
Panel discussion:

  •  ‘4-8 persons’ who are qualified to talk about the topic sit and discuss a given problem / topic in front of a target group of audience.
  •  Panel comprises of a chairman or moderator, and 4 – 8 speakers.
  • There is ‘no specific agenda, no order of speaking and no set speeches’.
  • After the speakers explore the topic, audience is invited to take part.
  • News channel discussions is a type of panel discussion.

Group discussion :

  • A group is an aggregation of people interacting in a face to – face situation.

questions.text: A rural PHC in a village was been examined for quality of health. All of the following are the objectives of Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) for Primary Health Centers except?

choices.text: Provision of comprehensive primary health care
Achievement of an acceptable quality of health care
Provision of accident and emergency care
Making services more responsive to the needs of the community

questions.solution:
Objectives of IPHS for PHC's:

  • Provision of comprehensive primary health care through PHC's
  • Achievement and maintenance of an acceptable standard of quality of health care
  • Making services more responsive and sensitive to the needs of community

questions.text: A sequence of activities in a health program to plan, schedule, monitor & furnish timely reports is known as PERT. PERT is a type of?
questions.solution:
PERT is a type of Network analysis

  • Management Methods & Techniques:
    • Based on principles of behavioral sciences + quantitative methods.
  • Quantitative Methods:
    • Derived from economics, operation research & budgeting
    • Role in Mx of health services.

Network Analysis
  •  
  • Graphic plan of all events , activities to be completed, to reach an end objective.
  • Greater discipline in planning.
  • Types (a) PERT ; (b) CPM.
  • a. PERT
    • Sequence of activities in a health program to plan , schedule , monitor & furnish tamely reports
  • b. CPM → Critical pathway method (longest path)

Systems Analysis
  •  
  • Comparision of 2/more cost- effective alternatives in a health program
  • Helps decision maker, to choose an appropriate course of action by investigating problem, searching/evaluating objectives, finding alternative solutions & evaluating them in terms of cost-effectiveness.

Input-Output Analysis:
  •  
  • It is an economic technique.
  • ‘Input’ refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials & time).
  • ‘output’ refers to such useful outcomes as cases treated, lives saved or inoculations performed.

Model

 

Cost–Benefit analysis
  •  
  • Output of health program is in monetory terms

Cost-Effective analysis
  •  
  • Output is in terms of results achieved

Cost–Accounting analysis
  •  
  • Provide some basic data on cost structure of a health program

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)
  •  
  • Allocation of resources to achieve objects in most effective way

Work sampling
  •  
  • Systematic observation & recording activities of 1/more individuals,done at predetermined / random intervals providing quantitative measurement of various activities.

Decision making

questions.text: The incidence of malaria in an area is 20, 20, 50, 56, 60, 5000, 678, 898, 345, 456. Which of these methods is the best to calculate the average incidence?
questions.solution:
In the given question, ·

  • Since extreme values (outliers) are present for incidence (20 and 5000), Median will be the most suitable measure of central tendency.
  • Incidence of malaria in an area is 20, 20, 50, 56, 60, 5000, 678, 898, 345, 456

and incidence in ascending order is 20, 20, 50, 56, 60, 345, 456, 678, 898, 5000

  • Mean = sum of all values/n = 7583/10 =758.3
  • Median = Mean (average)of 5th and 6th value = (60 + 345)/2 = 202.5
  • Mode = 20
  • Mean will not be an appropriate measure of central tendency since extreme values (outliers) are present.

questions.text: You have clinically diagnosed a patient as having SLE and ordered 6 tests, out of which 4 have come positive and 2 have negative. To know the probability of SLE at this point, you need to know:

questions.text: A 55 years male presented to medicine opd with complaints of weakness, dizziness,s, and syncopal attacks. Examination revealed bradycardia and hypotension. ECG was done. What is your diagnosis based upon the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
• PR interval is 200 msec (5 small squares) and is constant in the entire strip.
  • Every second P wave is not conducted to the ventricles resulting in dropped beats. This is a feature of the 2:1 conduction block. one p is followed by qrs complex other is not (2:1 block)
  •  It is highly likely to be misdiagnosed as a Mobitz II heart block.
  • In the case of third-degree heart block there is no relation between p wave and qrs complex.

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient clutches his chest and falls down. A physician arrives on the scene and finds the patient unresponsive with no breathing efforts. What is the first thing to be done by the physician?

A 37 yrs old, the female patient presents with complaints of weight loss despite increased appetite, heat intolerance, fatigue & weakness over the past few months. On examination, her HR was 120/min. She is noted to have protrusion of eyeballs. What would be her probable thyroid test report show?

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presented with complaints of chronic burning sensation associated with epigastric pain. On endoscopy & biopsy, he is found to have PUD & H.pylori. Which of the following drug is not effective in the management of this patient against H.Pylori?

questions.text: A 71-year-old male patient was brought in by his son to your outpatient clinic, with complaints of gradual cognitive decline which had started 3 years earlier. The patient is also noted to have a history of frequent forgetfulness and, memory impairment. On examination, his MMSE score was 16. Which of the following lobes are usually affected in such patients?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Alzheimer's disease.

  • AD presents with insidious onset of memory loss followed by slowly progressive dementia over several years.
  • Pathologically, atrophy is distributed throughout the medial temporal lobe and lateral and medial parietal lobes.
  • 4 A’s of Alzheimer’s disease are:
    • Amnesia:(Temporal #) Short term and Long term memory
    • Apraxia (Non dominant parietal lobe #)
    • Anosognosia
    • Aphasia (Dominant parietal lobe #)

questions.text: An elderly patient presents to OPD with a severe right-sided throbbing headache. She also gives a history of polymyalgia rheumatic. She also reports aching of the jaw during chewing. Lab investigation shows elevated ESR. All of the following statements are true regarding the given condition except:

choices.text: Most commonly seen in old age patients ( more than 50 yrs.)
Clinical features include constitutional symptoms like fever, fatigue, weight loss, and pain along the course of the temporal artery.
50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms varying from diplopia to complete vision loss
It usually involves the whole artery

questions.solution:
The given History and clinical findings point toward giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell arteritis

  • Rare before age 50.
  • Symptoms - constitutional—fever, fatigue, weight loss— or there may be facial pain or a headache, most intense along the course of the superficial temporal artery
  • Ocular symptoms (ophthalmic artery) appear abruptly in about 50% of patients; range from diplopia to complete vision loss
  • Giant cell arteritis can be extremely focal within an artery, adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment; even then, a negative biopsy result does not exclude the diagnosis.
  • Polymyalgia rheumatica is closely associated with GCA
  • O/E-
    • CORD like Structure at TM joint·
    • Ischemia skin of scalp- Temporal headache·
    • Ischemia of TMJ - Jaw claudication
  • Elevated ESR
  • Rx – Steroids. ( Prednisone at 40–60 mg daily for 1 month with gradual tapering)

questions.text: You are an intern, posted in the infectious ward in the department of internal medicine. You are seeing housekeeping staff disposing of the medical wastes without adequate protective equipment & are at risk of accidental needle stick injury. Which of the following infections would cause the maximum chance of spread in accidental needle stick injury?
questions.solution:
Percentage of chances of transmission of infection with accidental stick injury

22-30%

HBsAg positive and HBeAg Negative

1-6%

Hepatitis C

1.8-3%

HIV

0.3%

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to occur in a patient with the following hemodynamic data? Pressures: RA = 12 mm Hg, RV = 50/12 mm Hg, PA=50/15 mm Hg,PA wedge pressure = 8 mm Hg, Aorta=80/60,Cardiac Index = 1.4, SVR= 1800, PVR=500.

choices.text: Acute MI with LVF and cardiogenic shock

questions.solution:
Normal-pressure

Value given ( in mmHg)

Interpretation

RA = 2-6 mmHg

12

Elevated

RV = 25/5 mmHg

50/12

Elevated

Pulmonary artery = 25/10mmHg

50/15

Elevated

PCWP = 8 -12 mmHg

8

Normal

Aorta = < 120/80

80/60

Hypotension
  • The presence of Normal PCWP rules out the primary involvement of the left side heart. So Acute MI with LVF is ruled out.
  • Hypovolemic shock following Gastroenteritis will lead to under-filling of the right side of the heart but this patient has elevated pressure values on the right side of the heart.
  • Early septic shock will lead to increased cardiac output but this patient has hypotension. (ruled out)
  • Increased RA, PV pressure with PAH indicates RV malfunction. Less flow to the lungs will lead to systemic hypotension. Hence, the patient has a presentation of Acute Cor-Pulmonale.

questions.text: During a Zika virus outbreak, a 14-year-old girl presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and headache. She described diarrhea as watery and non-bloody. She was having 4 to 5 bowel movements a day accompanied by crampy, diffuse abdominal pain. Upon arrival, she was febrile at 101.4° F and tachycardic at 112 beats per minute. Her respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute and her blood pressure was 101/60 mm Hg. Which of the following clinical features is not seen in the case of Zika infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is an Atypical presentation of the Zika virus.

  • Zika fever presents with acute onset fever with pruritic maculopapular rash.
  • Concomitant non-purulent conjunctivitis and arthralgia occur and mimic chikungunya infection.
  • Symptoms last for about 7 days
  • Though it does not cause hemorrhagic complications, NSAIDS are avoided.

Neurological complications:

1) Microcephaly with brain calcification due to trans­placental passage

2) Guillain Barre Syndrome

Diagnosis:

  1. Zika Mac ELISA IgM neutralizing antibody detectable, 4 days after symptom onset.
  2. IgG antibody to Zika virus, 7 days after symptom onset.
  3. Trioplex real time RT-PCR assay on blood/ urine/ amniotic fluid/ CSF.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes with complaints of vomiting for the last 3 days. ABG report shows a pH = 7.22. pCO2 = 21 mm Hg and HCO3= 9 meq/dl. Diagnosis is?

choices.text: Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis
Mixed respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
• The pH shows acidosis and HCO3 is low indicating the primary derangement as metabolic acidosis. The patient will compensate with respiratory alkalosis.
  • To check for compensation Winter’s formula is applied = 1.5 X(HCO3) + 8 +2 = 1.5 x 9 + 8 + 2 = 21.5 + 2
  • Since the value of pCO2 of the patient is as per the calculation patient is having particularly compensated metabolic acidosis.
  • The patient will compensate with respiratory alkalosis.
  • If the value of pCO2 was less than 19.5 or more than 23.54 then mixed disorder would have been present.

questions.text: Rozer, a 19 years old male collapsed suddenly after running a few meters in a 200 m track event in school. He was rushed to a nearby hospital emergency where he was declared brought dead. A post-mortem was done to find out the t cause of death. Following is the heart specimen of the dead. All are true regarding the specimen shown except?

choices.text: Diamond-shaped cavity of the left ventricle

questions.solution:
• Most common cause of sudden death in young people is HOCM
  • The image shows a specimen of an enlarged heart with interventricular septal hypertrophy that is reducing the cavity size of the left ventricle. Thus it is an example of diastolic dysfunction as it reduces the end-diastolic volume significantly.
  • The presence of dynamic left ventricular hypertrophy results in low cardiac output.
  • Banana-shaped cavity of the left ventricle is seen with HOCM

questions.text: A 25yr old woman comes to OPD with a complaint of chest pain for the past 10hrs. She also mentions that she gets fatigued and feels breathless while doing routine activities. On auscultation, an early diastolic murmur is noted and ECG showed findings of LVH. The physician suspects a particular valvular condition. So he gently presses the femoral artery using a stethoscope and a to & fro murmur is heard. This finding is seen in which valvular heart condition?
questions.solution:
Duroziez’s sign is seen in severe aortic regurgitation

1. Duroziez Sign → Gently press the femoral artery using a stethoscope

↓

A murmur in the heart d/t turbulence

↓

To and fro murmur

Arterial pulse is seen with aortic regurgitation :

2. Corrigan’s pulse →Water hammer pulse

3. Quincke’s sign → Flushing and blanching at the distal part of the nail

4. Traube Sign → Pistol shot sounds heard at the femoral artery

questions.text: A 75yrs old, male patient diagnosed with Type 2 DM for the past 20yrs with poor metabolic control came with complaints of passing foamy urine. Blood analysis revealed glucose 200mg/dl, urea 52mg/dl, creatinine 1.2mg/dl, uric acid 5.3mg/dl. The physician suspected this condition as a complication of long-standing diabetes mellitus. Which of the following statement is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria
24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine
Microalbuminuria correlates with a nocturnal spike in Systolic blood pressure
Most common cause of death in type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
The above history & findings lead to the diagnosis of Diabetic Nephropathy

  • Sensitive radioimmunoassay methods measure small amounts of urinary albumin in contrast to less sensitive dipstick strips. Hence choice A is wrong.
  • 24-hour urine albumin values are affected by exercise, dietary protein, and sustained erect posture. This problem is circumvented with spot sample urine albumin to urine creatinine values. Hence choice B is wrong.
  • Most common cause of death in type 2 diabetes mellitus is myocardial infarction. Hence choice D is wrong.

questions.text: A 52 yrs old plumber came with complaints of severe pain & swelling over the big toe. On examination, his BP was 165/95mmHg & also had signs of progressive renal failure. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The triad of ‘saturnine gout’ + hypertension + renal failure is seen in Lead nephropathy.
  • Saturnine gout
  • Cause - Lead toxicity
  • Symptoms of lead toxicity precede the development of gout.
    • Hence patient will have anemia, basophilic stippling of RBC, abdominal pain, and nerve palsy
    • The damage to the kidney will lead to hypertension and progressive renal malfunction.
    • Knee joint involvement is more common than MTP involvement in saturnine gout

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. He also has a family history of ADPKD. How should the cysts be present in USG to call it ADPKD?
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria for ADPKD

Age (years )

Number of Cysts(USG FINDING)

15-29

2 renal cysts (unilateral or bilateral) + family history of ADPKD

30-59

2 cysts per kidney + family history of ADPKD

>60

4 cysts per kidney + family history of ADPKD

Genetic testing (linkage analysis and direct DNA sequencing) is available as a clinical test and can detect PKD1 and PKD2 mutations in approximately 90% of confirmed cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anemia. Duodenal biopsy shows complete villous atrophy, Probable diagnosis can be ascertained on detection of which antibody :
questions.solution:
The differential diagnosis of this patient is Celiac disease

  1. Best screening test for diagnosis of celiac sprue -Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody > Anti-endomysial antibody
  2. Malabsorption and anaemia are seen due to  disease affecting the proximal gut > distal part of the small intestine
  3. Biopsy from distal duodenum or proximal jejunum - loss or blunting of the intestinal mucosa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient on regular OCPs presented with complaints of intermittent colicky pain. HPE of the bowel wall and regional lymph node showed characteristically non-caseating granuloma with Langerhans giant cells. The consultant doctor is suspecting Crohn's disease. Which of the following is the best screening test for Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
• ASCA-positive (anti-saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody) seen with 70% of CD and 15% of UC patients.
  • p-ANCA positivity is found in about 60-70% of UC patients and 5-10% of CD patients
  • Fecal calprotectin levels correlate well with histologic inflammation, predict relapses, and detect pouchitis

questions.text: A 22 years male presented to OPD with complaints of persistent painful erection for 6 hours. He also gives history of severe anemia in early childhood requiring many transfusions and h/o nonhealing leg ulcers and recurrent periods of abdominal and chest pain. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Non-healing leg ulcers, severe anemia & recurring painful crises are characteristic of the diagnosis of Sickle cell anemia.
  • Priapism refers to a persistent (> 4 hours) and painful erection.
  • It occurs due to:
    • An excessive release of neurotransmitters
    • Blockage of draining venules (e.g., mechanical interference in sickle cell crisis, leukemia, or excessive use of intravenous parenteral lipids)
    • Prolonged relaxation of the intracavernous smooth muscles (most often caused by the use of exogenous smooth-muscle relaxants such as injectable intra-cavernosal prostaglandin E1).

questions.text: A 43 yr old female presented to med opd with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath with minimal activity. Her friends and family have told her she appears pale and combined with her recent symptoms she has decided to get checked out. She also states that she has noticed her hair and fingernails becoming extremely thin and brittle, causing even more concern. The patient first started noticing these symptoms a few months ago and they have been getting progressively worse. Upon initial assessment, her mucosal membranes and conjunctivae are pale. Considering the above scenario the most sensitive and specific test to diagnose this particular type of deficiency anemia is:
questions.solution:
• This is the classic presentation of Iron deficiency anemia
  • Serum ferritin levels are the most sensitive and specific test to diagnose iron-deficiency anemia
  • Under steady-state conditions, the serum ferritin level correlates with total body iron stores; thus, the serum ferritin level is the most convenient laboratory test to estimate iron stores. The normal value for ferritin varies according to the age and gender of the individual. As iron stores are depleted, the serum ferritin falls to <15 μg/L. Such levels are diagnostic of absent body iron stores.
  • Adult males have serum ferritin levels that average ∼100 μg/L, corresponding to iron stores of ∼1 g.
  • Adult females have lower serum ferritin levels averaging 30 μg/L, reflecting lower iron stores (∼300 mg).
  • Ferritin is also an acute-phase reactant and, in the presence of acute or chronic inflammation, may rise several-fold above baseline levels.

questions.text: Mr. Ramesh, a businessman has taken multiple bank loans from a nationalized bank and is unable to make payments. He has been brought for psychiatric evaluation as recently he has been denying any memory of taking loans from the bank. Interestingly, all other memory functioning is pretty intact. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Dissociative Amnesia

  • Commonest clinical type of dissociative disorder.
  • Occurs mostly in late adolescence and young adults.
  • Severe psychological trauma
  • The patient temporarily and unconsciously shuts down the memory of the traumatic event
  • Circumscribed loss of traumatic memory is seen in these individuals
  • The other memories are intact and this cannot be explained by normal forgetting

Treatment:

    • Supportive psychotherapy, cognitive therapy, hypnosis.
    • Identify trauma related cognitive distortions and help the individual cope with adaptive behaviours
    • Drug assisted interview could be beneficial to elicit information- abreaction (not recommended in children)

Option 2 - It's not fugue, as all other memory functions would also be disturbed in fugue.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child disturbs other people, is destructive, interferes when two people are talking, does not follow instructions and cannot wait for his turn while playing a game. Which of the following is he likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
This child has symptoms of hyperactivity and impulsivity and the most likely diagnosis would be attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Symptoms of ADHD:

  • Inattention
  • Hyperactivity
  • Impulsivity
  • Other symptoms - Destructive behaviour, irritability, and aggression.

PONTER in Q = cannot wait for turn which indicates impulsivity.

questions.text: Researchers posit that melatonin secretion acts as the biological substrate for the internal circadian oscillator. Ingested melatonin can reach and bind to melatonin-binding sites in the brains of mammals and produce somnolence when used at high doses. Melatonin is produced in all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Melatonin

  • Sleep hormone
  • Pineal gland produces melatonin
  • Melatonin is produced in the retina from photoreceptors and shows a local neuromodulatory action.
  • Melatonin is also produced by enterochromaffin cells throughout the gut
  • It works on melatonin receptors (M1 and M2) on the Suprachiasmatic nucleus
  • Synchronizes the circadian rhythm with day and night change

HOW TO REMEMBER: Gut is the second brain. So, melatonin is produced there also.

questions.text: Conditions that may predispose to, or aggravate, withdrawal symptoms include fatigue, malnutrition, physical illness, and depression. Mild symptoms usually show up as early as 6 hours after you put down your glass in Alcohol withdrawal. First symptom to appear in alcohol withdrawal is?
questions.solution:
Tremors usually appear 6-8 hours after last alcohol intake.

Withdrawal symptoms:

  • After 6-8 hrs: Tremors (m/c), nausea, vomiting restlessness, mydriasis
  • After 8-12hrs: Alcoholic hallucinosis (auditory) m/c
  • After 12-24hrs: Alcohol withdrawal seizures (GTCS, clustered seizures)
  • During first 72 hrs but may develop any time in the first week: delirium tremens, if untreated mortality rate is 20%

HOW TO REMEMBER: eighT=Tremors, 11= ha11ucinations, 22=SeiSure, TRemes= within ThRee days

questions.text: A 17 year old female underwent FNAC for a lump in the breast which was non-tender, firm and mobile. Histopathology reveals tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with discohesive bare nuclei . What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Phyllodes- leaf-like appearance on cut section. Dual origin of mammary epithelium and connective tissue (stroma)

LCIS - Indian File Pattern

DCIS - May show cribriform, comedo ,or papillary growth pattern.

Tightly arranged epithelial cells with discohesive bare nuclei are suggestive of benign breast disease likely Fibroadenoma

questions.text: A known case of portal hypertension comes to your clinic with the following features as shown in the image. The characteristic auscultatory sound that can be heard over this finding is:
questions.solution:
Porto-Systemic Anastomosis

Location

Portal component

Systemic component

Esophagus varices

Left gastric vein

Azygous vein and Accessory Hemiazygous Vein

Rectum and anal Canal Hemorrhoids

Superior rectal vein

Middle and Inferior Rectal Vein

Umbilicus Caput medusa

Left branch of portal vein

Superficial epigastric veins

Posterior abdominal wall

Colic and omental veins

Retroperitoneal veins of abdominal wall, Renal capsule, Splenic and Hepatic Flexure

Bare area of liver

Hepatic venules Right branch of portal vein

Phrenic and Intercostal veins, Retroperitoneal veins draining into lumbar, azygous, and hemiazygous veins

Liver

Patent ductus venosus left branch of portal vein

Inferior vena cava

Audible Venous hum at caput medusa → Cruveilhier Baumgarten Murmur

questions.text: Endoscopy was done on a 50-year-old female with severe gastritis. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed severe pain and swelling in the neck with crepitus suggestive of iatrogenic esophageal perforation. Which part of the esophagus is most susceptible to this type of injury?
questions.solution:
The cervical portion of the esophagus is most susceptible to iatrogenic esophageal perforation

Common sites of esophageal perforation

Anatomic landmark

Description

Piriform sinus

Trumpet players, manual labourers and singers are prone to develop piriform sinus perforations

Killian triangle

Pharyngoesophageal diverticula occur here and inadvertent cannulation of the diverticulum results in perforation

Cricopharyngeous muscle

Most common site of iatrogenic perforation

Aortic arch/bronchus

Esophagus is in direct contact with the aortic arch and bronchus which both create a small indentation on esophagram

Gastroesophageal junction

Most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome

Etiology

Esophageal perforation

Iatrogenic

Spontaneous
  • Most common type(60%)
  • Caused by endoscopy
  • Most common site is the cervical esophagus (cricopharyngeal area)
  • Esophageal rupture after vomiting
  • Most common site: left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus

 

Clinical features

  • Pain - striking and consistent symptom and strongly suggests that an esophageal rupture has occurred, particularly in the cervical area following instrumentation of the esophagus or substernally in a patient with vomiting
  • If subcutaneous emphysema is present, the diagnosis is almost certain
  • Suspicion of esophageal perforation begins with symptoms of –
    • Epigastric or chest pain
    • Epigastric tenderness
    • Neck or throat pain
    • Crepitus on the neck, chest or face
    • Neck swelling
    • Nasal voice
    • Dysphagia
  • Within the first 8 to 24 hours following injury, frank sepsis may develop if the contamination is extensive
  • Mediastinal emphysema, a strong indication of perforation takes at least 1 hour to be demonstrated and is present only in 40% of patients
  • Mediastinal widening secondary to edema may not occur for several hours
  • In cervical perforation, cervical emphysema is common and mediastinal emphysema is rare, the converse is true for thoracic perforation
  • If mediastinal pleura ruptures, pneumothorax appears rapidly

questions.text: A 7-year-old female complained of worsening left-sided abdominal pain in the last 6 days before hospital admission. The pain intensified while urinating. She also experienced fever for 4 days. She also had occasional bed-wetting as a 7-year-old. On her medical history, she had frequently visited the pediatrician for similar symptoms since she was 3 years old, and was treated for UTI. Vital signs were normal and on abdominal examination, she had left lower quadrant and left costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory values showed that she had normal blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine, but had evidence of infection in the urinalysis result. Other laboratory results were unremarkable. Intravenous pyelography was done which showed the findings shown in the image. True about the treatment of this condition:

choices.text: If the function of the upper pole ureter is normal then no intervention is needed and for lower pole ureter uterovesicoplasty can be done
Both the poles should be excised and reimplanted into the bladder as the patient may become susceptible to UTI more common
For Upper pole hydronephrosis with no function, an Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed
The lower pole ureter is prone to develop Ureteocele so it can be managed after evaluating the patient with IVP

questions.solution:
DUPLICATION OF URETER (AD)

  • MC congenital anomaly of the upper urinary tract.
  • Mode of inheritance is autosomal dominant.
  • More common in females
  • Unilateral duplication is more common than bilateral
  • Left side more commonly involved
  • Yo-Yo effect in fused ureter (incomplete duplication) is seen
  • Complete duplication occurs when there are two separate ureteric buds
  • In complete duplication, upper pole Ureteral orifice in the bladder is caudal and medial to lower pole of Ureteral orifice (Weigert Meyer rule)
  • Upper pole ureter is associated with Ureterocele
  • Lower pole ureter is associated with Short intravesical length of the ureter( risk of VUR)
  • Diagnosis - IVP: Shows duplication In most of the cases.

Treatment -

  • If the function of Upper pole ureter is normal- Excision and reimplantation into the bladder
  • If the function of Upper pole ureter is impaired- upper pole nephrectomy
  • Lower pole ureter- Ureterovesicoplasty

questions.text: A 54 years male patient got admitted to a private hospital with a chief complaint of bulging of veins in both lower limbs. He had started noticing lower extremity swelling about 5 years ago and then for 1 year has been plagued with progressive leg pain. On the Doppler test, abnormal blood flow in lower limbs was noted. A diagnosis of B/L varicose veins of lower limbs was made. The patient was posted for surgery and the varicose veins were stripped successfully from ankle to groin bilaterally. The most common complication that you can expect after varicose vein stripping is:
questions.solution:
Complications of varicose vein surgery

  • Recurrence (MC): Incidence of recurrence after surgery in upto 10%.
  • Hematoma or Ecchymosis: MC cause of discomfort after varicose vein surgery
  • Sensory nerve injury
  • Greater saphenous vein should only be stripped to just below the knee to avoid damage to the accompanying saphenous nerve
  • Sural nerve must be carefully dissected off the lesser saphenous vein at the ankle.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented to the OPD with second-degree burns which he developed when his shirt caught fire accidentally. The percentage of burns is 20%. Patient was immediately resuscitated with fluids. Fluid of choice is :
questions.solution:
• Ringer Lactate is most commonly used
  • Some centers use human albumin, FFP, or hypertonic saline
  • Intravenous resuscitation is appropriate for any child with a burn greater than 10% TBSA and 15% TBSA for adults
  • The most widely used and simplest formula to calculate fluid requirement is the Parkland formula

Volume = total percentage body surface area x weight (kg) x 4

Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours

questions.text: A 30 years old male complains of loss of erection; he has low testosterone levels and high prolactin levels in the blood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 30-year-old male has low testosterone levels which may be due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, testicular failure, or prolactinoma. But since the prolactin levels are high, prolactinoma which is a pituitary adenoma is the cause of low testosterone and loss of erection

Pituitary adenomas

  • Pituitary adenomas arise from the anterior pituitary gland.
  • They may be microadenoma < 10 mm in size or macroadenomas >10 mm in size.
  • They may be functional or non-functional.
  • The most common endocrine syndromes produced by functional tumors  include Cushing’s disease(ACTH) , Forbes Albright Syndrome (prolactin), and Acromegaly (growth hormone) . 
  • Thirty percent of adenomas are prolactinomas, 20% are non functioning, 15% secrete growth hormone and 10% secrete ACTH
  • Features of note in the initial assessment include any
  • History of galactorrhoea in females and impotence in males, infertility in both (suggestive of prolactinoma)
  • Cushingoid (classic hyperpigmentation of the skin and mucous membrane, ecchymosis, and purple striae pointing to ACTH secreting tumors or
  • Acromegalic features pointing to growth hormone-secreting tumours
  • Baseline assessment of pituitary function should include serum prolactin( levels more than 150ng/mL is considered diagnostic of prolactinoma) , follicle stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone together with testosterone in males or oestradiol in females, thyroid function tests, and fasting serum growth hormone and cortisol
  • Prolactinomas are managed initially with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline. Compression of the chiasm with any evidence of visual compromise is the main indication for urgent surgical intervention. Surgical resection is usually performed trans nasally via a transsphenoidal approach. Complications of surgery include CSF leak, pituitary insufficiency ,and diabetes insipidus
  • Craniopharyngiomas are benign cystic lesions that occur in the sellar region most frequently in children. The second peak of incidence also exists around 50 years of age. Symptoms result from compression of adjacent structures, especially the optic chiasm. Pituitary or hypothalamic dysfunction or hydrocephalus may develop. Treatment is primarily surgical.

questions.text: Frey’s syndrome occurs due to aberrant misdirection of fibers from salivary glands to sweat glands. These fibers come from which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Frey’s syndrome occurs due to aberrant misdirection of fibers from salivary glands to sweat glands. These fibers come from auriculotemporal nerve.
  • FREY’S SYNDROME (AURICULOTEMPORAL SYNDROME or GUSTATORY SWEATING)
  • It results from damage to auriculotemporalQ nerve during dissection in parotidectomy
  • Aberrant cross innervations between secretomotor parasympathetic fibers of parotid gland and sympathetic fibers supplying the sweat glandQ
  • CLINICAL FEATURES - Sweating and erythema over the region of parotid glands as a consequence of autonomic stimulation of salivation by smell or taste of food.
  • DIAGNOSIS: Minor’s starch iodine testQ
  • TREATMENT -
  • Antiperspirant (aluminium chloride) applicationQ
  • Botulinum toxin treatment is used for symptomatic Frey’s syndrome (most effective treatmentQ)
  • Surgical interruption of secretary fibers by tympanic neurectomyQ, in non-responding cases

questions.text: A 56-year-old man attends having knocked his finger while working in the garage. He reports having had a small lump on his finger for some months and, since knocking his finger, this has been leaking, as shown below. What is the single most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Myxoid cysts
  • Ganglions of the distal interphalangeal joint.
  • They grow slowly and often cause grooving of the nail as they grow.
  • They are benign but can become painful.
  • Treatment is by aspiration of the thick jelly inside or injection with steroid, or surgical excision if they recur.
  • A keratoacanthoma has a plug of keratin in the center.
  • Pyogenic granuloma usually grows rapidly at the site of trauma.
  • Sebaceous cysts are not typically seen on digits.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought by his mother with a c/o mass in the abdomen. The parent’s medical history was insignificant. He was the second child of a healthy nonconsanguineous parent. In laboratory tests, serum catecholamines, urinary vanillyl mandelic acid, and homovanillic acid levels were found to be elevated. CT scan was done which revealed a mass of 4x2x2cm in size just above the kidneys. All of the following statements about the diagnosis of this case are true except:

choices.text: Most common site involved is thoracic cavity
Localised lesions are treated by excision

questions.solution:
2 year old male child with elevated levels of urinary catecholamine metabolites is suggestive of a tumour arising from adrenal medulla – Neuroblastoma

  • NEUROBLASTOMA
  • Most common extracranial solid tumour in infants and children
  • Arise from neural crest cells
  • Malignant neoplasm of the sympathetic nervous system
  • Third most common paediatric malignancy
  • Over 80% of cases present before the age of 4 years and peak incidence is 2 yrs
  • Most common site:65% occur in abdomen with 50% localised to the adrenal medulla, neck (5%), chest (20%) or pelvis (5%)
  • Clinical features
  • Asymptomatic
  • Constitutional symptoms
  • Enlarging mass, Pain, Abdominal distension
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Respiratory distress
  • Bladder or bowel disturbance
  • Horner syndrome
  • Periorbital swelling and proptosis (raccoon eyes)
  • Blueberry muffin syndrome (blue subcutaneous nodules)
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes (intractable diarrhea)
  • Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • Diagnosis –
  • Elevated levels of urinary catecholamines and their metabolites(vanillyl mandelic acid or homovanillic acid)
  • Elevated levels of lactate dehydrogenase (>1500U/ml)
  • Elevated levels of ferritin ( >142ng/mL)
  • Elevated levels of neuron specific enolase ( >100ng/mL)
  • Histology - Undifferentiated small round blue cells
  • Modified Shimda classification - helps to predict prognosis
  • TREATMENT
  • Localized neuroblastoma: Excision
  • Unresectable tumor: Biopsy, initially treated by chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical resection of residual tumor
  • Disseminated disease: Chemotherapy(Cyclophosphamide, vincristine, dacarbazine, doxorubicin, Cisplatin)

questions.text: A 45-year-old housewife presented to the emergency department with complaints of excessive drowsiness and decreased oral intake for the past 3 days. In the last three years, she also had difficulty getting up from the squatting position, combing her hair, and dressing. These difficulties were gradually progressive with no diurnal variations or periodic fluctuations. She complained of increased sensitivity to cold, dryness of skin, increased hair loss, hoarseness of voice, and easy fatigability. She had no history of intake of any prescribed or over-the-counter medications. She also had no history or family history of any major illnesses. On physical examination periorbital puffiness and dry, coarse skin were noted. No tremors or fasciculations were elicited. Your probable diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
A probable diagnosis is a hypothyroidism. The deficiency of circulating levels of thyroid hormone leads to hypothyroidism

Hypothyroidism signs and symptoms may include:

  • Fatigue
  • Increased sensitivity to cold
  • Constipation
  • Dry skin (due to reduced conversion of carotene to vitamin A)
  • Weight gain
  • Puffy face (Patients with severe hypothyroidism or myxedema develop characteristic facial features due to the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the subcutaneous tissue leading to facial and periorbital puffiness )
  • Hoarseness
  • Muscle weakness
  • Elevated blood cholesterol level
  • Muscle aches, tenderness, and stiffness
  • Pain, stiffness, or swelling in your joints
  • Heavier than normal or irregular menstrual periods
  • Infertility
  • Thinning hair
  • Loss of outer two thirds of eyebrow
  • Slowed heart rate
  • Depression
  • Impaired memory
  • Enlarged thyroid gland (goiter)
  • Cardiovascular changes include bradycardia, cardiomegaly, pericardial effusion, reduced cardiac output and pulmonary effusion
  • Hypothyroidism in children leads to cretinism and characteristic facies

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of abdominal pain for the past 3 days. She localizes the pain to her epigastric area and states that it radiates to her right upper quadrant. She notes that it became markedly worse after eating dinner last night. She recalls a past history of similar pain but has never had any diagnostic workup. She gives history of total abdominal hysterectomy 1 year ago. Her abdominal exam is significant for tenderness to palpation to her epigastric and right upper quadrants without rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds are normal. Based on USG and CT a diagnosis of choledocholithiasis was made. The patient was operated and the stones were removed (shown in the image). What is the composition of the stone?

choices.text: Calcium oxalate + Calcium phosphate + Calcium stearate
Calcium bilirubinate+ Calcium palmitate + Calcium stearate
Insoluble bilirubin polymer + Calcium phosphate + Calcium bicarbonate
Insoluble bilirubin polymer + Calcium phosphate + Calcium carbonate

questions.solution:
The stones shown in the image are brown stones

Gallstones

The major organic solutes in bile are bilirubin, bile salts, phospholipids and cholesterol. Gallstones are classified by their cholesterol content as either Cholesterol stones or Pigment stones. Pigment stones can be further classified as either black or brown.

  • In the USA and Europe, 80% are cholesterol or mixed stones, whereas in Asia, 80% are pigment stones
  • Cholesterol or mixed stones - 51-99% pure cholesterol plus an admixture of calcium salts, bile acids, bile pigments and phospholipids
  • Pigmented stones contain <20% of cholesterol and are dark because of the presence of calcium bilirubinate
  • Black stones - Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate
  • Brown pigment stones- calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate+ cholesterol
  • Black pigment stones are usually small, brittle, dark and sometimes spiculated. They are formed by supersaturation of unconjugated bilirubin within the bile which occurs due to its increased production (haemolytic disorders) or in cirrhosis. The insoluble unconjugated bilirubin will then precipitate with calcium as insoluble calcium bilirubinate, forming a pigment stone. Pigment stones are often radiopaque. They are found almost exclusively in the gallbladder. More prevalent in Asian population
  • Brown stones are brownish yellow, soft and mushy. They may form either in the gallbladder or in the bile ducts secondary to bacterial infection and bile stasis. Bacteria such as Escherichia coli secrete β glucuronidase that enzymatically cleaves conjugated bilirubin to produce the insoluble unconjugated bilirubin which then precipitates with calcium, and along with dead bacterial cell bodies forms soft brown stones in the biliary tree. Brown stones occur due to parasitic infection with Ascaris lumbricoides(roundworm) or Clonorchis sinesis (liver fluke)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the OPD with complaints of loss of appetite and early satiety. On endoscopic evaluation, an ulceroproliferative lesion in the stomach was noted. Biopsy of the lesion is suggestive of gastric adenocarcinoma. Type 1 gastric cancer according to Bormann’s classification is:
questions.solution:
Bormann Classification of gastric carcinoma (Based on macroscopic appearance)

Type I

Polypoid or fungating cancers

Type II

Ulcerated with elevated borders

Type III

Ulcerated lesions infiltrating the gastric wall

Type IV

Infiltrates diffusely (Linnitis plastic)

Type V

Unable to be classified

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presented to your clinic complaining of lower belly pain and increased urinary frequency for seven months. Her daytime urinary frequency ranged from 20 to 35 times with nocturia about six to eight times. She experienced no associated symptoms such as fever, weight/appetite changes, bowel habits, or any antecedent infection. The patient’s past medical, surgical, and family history was unremarkable. Systemic examination was unexceptional except for suprapubic tenderness. Her urinalysis and urine culture were insignificant. Cystoscopy was done which revealed the following finding shown in the image. True about the management of this condition is

choices.text: Conservative management; Has a good prognosis
Application of dimethyl-sulphoxide into the bladder

questions.solution:
Interstitial cystitis (Hunner’s ulcer)

  • Characterized by Chronic Pancystitis
  • Infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages
  • MC in females
  • Etiology is unknown
  • Presence of linear bleeding ulcer in the fundus (involving mucosa)
  • Clinical features
  • Initial symptom - Increased frequency
  • Pain increased by distention of bladder & relieved by micturition
  • Bladder capacity is reduced to 30 – 50ml
  • Diagnosis
  •   On Cystoscopy – presence of linear bleeding ulcer in fundus
  • To rule out malignancy:
  • Urinary cytology
  • Biopsy
     
  • Treatment
  • Difficult and unsatisfactory
  • Bladder distention under anesthesia
  • Instillation of dimethyl-sulphoxide into the bladder

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy presented with swelling of his left foot, leg, and right hand since 5days of his age. Initially, the swelling was confined to the foot and then it was gradually progressing with involvement of his left foot and leg which was grossly edematous. There was no known family history of limb swelling. His physical examination revealed non-pitting edema of the left foot, left leg, and right hand. The diagnosis of idiopathic primary congenital lymphedema was confirmed by isotopic lymphatic scintigraph. All the following operations/procedures can be done for congenital lymphedema except:
questions.solution:
Treatment of Lymphedema

  • Most (95%) of patients can be managed non – operativelyQ
  • Use of external compressive garments and devices
  • Limb elevation
  • Antibiotics for episodes of cellulitisQ.

Surgical treatment of Lymphedema

Excisional operations

  • Only viable option for patients without residual lymphatics of adequate size for a reconstructive procedure
  • Sistrunk
    • A wedge of skin and subcutaneous tissue is excised and the wound closed primarily
  • Kontoleon’s or Homan’s
    • Staged subcutaneous excision underneath flaps.
  • Thompson
    • A denudeded skin flap is sutured to the deep fascia and buried beneath the second skin flap (buried dermal flap)
  • Charles procedure:
    • In severe lymphedema with unhealthy and infected skin.

questions.text: Following a small-bowel resection, a 49 years old male develops fever and anemia. The surface surrounding the surgical wound is warm to the touch and necrotizing fasciitis is suspected. Another manifestation that would most suggest necrotizing fasciitis is:
questions.solution: Severe pressure like pain out of proportion to visible signs distinguishes necrotizing fasciitis from cellulitis. Erythema, leukocytosis, and swelling are present in both cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant has undergone surgical treatment for meningomyeloencephalocele. At birth, an operation was carried out in the posterior cranial fossa to partially replace brain cerebellar contents to an intracranial position. In investigations for progressive hydrocephalus, it is noted that there is herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, and a diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari syndrome is established. This syndrome may also include which of the following?

choices.text: Fusion of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes
Abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves
Partial or complete absence of the pituitary gland

questions.solution:
• Abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves may be evident in Arnold-Chiari syndrome.
  • Additional features include fusion of the corpora quadrigemina, leading to a “beaked” tectum; the partial or complete absence of the corpus callosum; and microgyria.

questions.text: A nerve injured in radical neck dissection leads to loss of sensation in the medial side of the arm, nerve-injured is?
questions.solution:
• Nerve injured in radical neck dissection leads to loss of sensation in the medial side of the arm, nerve-injured is the medial cutaneous nerve of arm.
  • The medial cutaneous nerve of the arm supplies the skin of the medial aspect of the arm.
  • It is the smallest branch of the brachial plexus, arises from the medial cord, and contains fibers from the eighth cervical and first thoracic ventral rami.

questions.text: A mass casualty of 20 patients was brought to the casualty. They were injured during a landslide in their area and were immediately rushed to the hospital. Which of the following color code and explanations is matched correctly as per the triage used in disaster management?

choices.text: Yellow-Stable patients, observation required in hospital.

questions.solution:
Yellow colour in triage indicates stable patients and observation is required in the hospital

TRIAGE

  • Triage means to “sort”, especially used for mass-casualties
  • Involves prioritizing victims into categories based on: Severity of injury, likelihood of survival & urgency of care

Priority

Colour

Medical need

Clinical status

Examples

First

Red

Immediate

Critical, likely to survive if the treatment is given early

Tension pneumothorax, Extradural hematoma

Second

Yellow

Urgent

Critical, likely to survive if treatment given within hours

Degloving injuries, pelvic fractures

Third

Green

Non urgent

Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days


Simple fractures, sprains, minor laceration

Last

Black

Unsalvageable

Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Severe brain damage, very extensive burns

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman was transplanted pre-emptively with a kidney from a deceased donor. Her immunosuppressive treatment included thymoglobulin, and tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetyl (MMF), methylprednisolone. Ten months later, the patient started complaining of pain on urination associated with fever,muscle pain, and weakness. On laboratory examination, a positive urinalysis for decoy cell preceded a rise in creatinine to 2mg/dL. Which of the following can be a viral etiological agent?

choices.text: Human papilloma virus, high risk types

questions.solution:
Polyoma BK virus

  • BK virus is polyoma virus associated with nephropathy, typically after transplant
  • Polyoma viruses can become dormant in kidneys and can be activated by immunosuppression
  • High levels of BK viremia are associated with the development of ureteric strictures, Polyoma virus associated nephropathy, and generalized vasculopathy
  • Timely detection and early reduction of immunosuppression are critical and can reduce rates of graft loss related to polyoma virus associated nephropathy from 90% to 10-30%
  • Renal biopsy is necessary for diagnosis

Most common opportunistic infections in renal transplant recipients:

Peritransplant (<1 month )

  • Wound infections
  • Herpes virus
  • Oral candidiasis
  • Urinary tract infection

Late (>6 months)

  • Aspergillus
  • Nocardia
  • BK virus (polyoma)
  • Herpes zoster
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C

Early ( 1-6 months)

  • Pneumocytis carinii
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Legionella
  • Listeria
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C

questions.text: A 40-year-old female underwent parathyroidectomy for parathyroid hyperplasia. On the 2nd postoperative day, the patient developed a positive Chvostek and Trousseau sign. His serum calcium levels were found to be 7 mg/dL. This is due to:
questions.solution:
• The patient has underwent parathyroidectomy after which he developed signs of hypocalcemia (positive Chvostek and Trousseau sign) and his calcium levels are decreased
  • Hypocalcemia in the immediate post-operative period following surgery for parathyroid gland is due to increased uptake by bones (Hungry Bone Syndrome)

questions.text: A 10-year-old obese boy was referred to the emergency with a history of hip pain. He was observed to be limping and complained of severe pain. Which of the following investigation is not required?
questions.solution:
Order of Investigations in any inflammatory Joint Swelling

X-ray

↓

MRI

↓

Aspiration

This patient is an Obese limping child with hip pain, the possible differential diagnosis would be:

  • Osteomyelitis (X-MAS)
  • Septic arthritis (X-MAS)
  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (X-MRI)
  • Transient synovitis (X-MAS)
  • Hence CT will be least preferred.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive swellings at upper end of tibia – irregular, local temperature raised, invariable consistency and ill-defined margins. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation in question can occur both in Ewing’s sarcoma and osteosarcoma.
  • However, swelling is around the knee joint at upper end of tibia, which favours the diagnosis of osteosarcoma (metaphyseal lesion).
  • Ewing’s sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphysis of the bone (middle of the shaft).
  • Giant cell tumor site- Epiphysis
  • Secondary metastasis occurs in old age usually.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with musculoskeletal complaints. The main concern is to differentiate articular versus non-articular origin of pain. Which of the following feature is suggestive of non-articular origin of pain?

choices.text: Pain or decreased range of motion on active and passive movement both
Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

questions.solution:
Differentiation between articular and extraarticular joint disorders

  • Articular disorders are characterized by internal/deep joint pain that is exacerbated by active and passive motion and by reduced range of motion.
  • Extraarticular disorders are associated with joint pain with active motion rather than passive motion in addition, range of motion often is preserved.

A crepitation is never present in a joint disorder or pain and usually present in fractures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady presented with nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. X-Ray was done which showed centrally located lytic lesions in metacarpals as shown. Next line of management will be:

choices.text: Parathyroid hormone and serum calcium levels measurement

questions.solution:
The above x-ray depicts- Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism which is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on the radial aspect.

Other X-ray Features of Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Osteoporosis (sometimes including vertebral collapse) and areas of cortical
    erosion
  • Hyperparathyroid ‘Brown Tumors’: atypical cyst-like lesions of long bones
  • Subperiosteal cortical resorption of the middle phalanges: The classical – and almost pathognomonic – feature as in this case.
  • Don’t confuse it with enchondroma because middle age and female gender point it more towards hyperparathyroidism.
  • Parathyroid hormone and serum calcium levels measurement is required to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was admitted in casualty with a history of sustained head injury from road traffic accident. His Glasgow coma scale was 7/15. The senior resident of anesthesia advised the resident to secure a definitive airway device. The airway device that could not be used in this patient is-
questions.solution:
• Tracheal intubation is a definitive airway, provides maximal protection against aspiration of gastric contents and allows positive pressure ventilation with a high airway pressure than via a face mask or supraglottic airway.
  • LMA is temporary airway device since it cannot prevent aspiration.
  • Invasive airways (Tracheostomy) are indicated as a rescue technique when attempts of non-invasive techniques failed.

LMA

  • The Laryngeal Mask Airway is a supraglottic airway device which sits in the hypopharynx and forms a seal around the periglottic tissues.
  • The seal around the laryngeal inlet allows for the delivery of oxygen and volatile agents during spontaneous ventilation and permits positive pressure ventilation at pressures up to 20 cm H2O.
  • Once positioned, the cuff should be inflated with the minimum volume of air, with a target cuff pressure of 60 cm H2O.
  • It can be used for ventilation as a primary airway management device, rescue airway device, and a conduit for tracheal intubation.

Advantages:

  • Easy and rapid
  • Less invasive
  • Better hemodynamic stability
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Lack of need for muscle relaxation
  • Requires lesser plane of Anaesthesia
  • Avoidance of risk of some risks of tracheal intubation (trauma to teeth and airway, sore throat, coughing on emergence, bronchospasm)

Disadvantages:

  • Supraglottic airway devices have comparatively lesser seal pressures than tracheal tubes which leads to ineffective ventilation when higher airway pressures required
  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration when first-generation Supraglottic airway devices used
  • No protection from laryngospasm
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who was a case of polytrauma due to a road traffic accident came to casualty. On examination, blood pressure was not recordable, carotid pulse was not felt and immediately cardiopulmonary resuscitation started according to ACLS guidelines. The monitor showed pulseless electrical activity. Which of the following is the least probable cause for pulseless electrical activity in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pulseless electrical activity (PEA) refers to the presence of organized electrical activity without a palpable pulse.

Mnemonic to remember the reversible causes of pulseless electrical activity is:

  • MAD (triple H) CAT

Mnemonic

  • M: Massive pulmonary/coronary embolism
  • A: Acidosis
  • D: Drug overdose(digitalis, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, tricyclic antidepressants, toxins)
  • H: Hypoxia/hypothermia
  • H: Hypovolaemia
  • H: Hypokalaemia/hyperkalaemia
  • C: Cardiac tamponade
  • A: Acute myocardial infarction
  • T: Tension pneumothorax

Prompt initiation of chest compressions and administration of 1mg epinephrine are recommended as temporary measures until the definitive therapy can be provided once the cause for PEA is identified. Asystole or ventricular fibrillation can develop if PEA untreated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who was a case of both bone fracture right forearm posted for open reduction and internal fixation with plating under bier block using local anesthetics which has least vasodilatation. The drug used in this patient would be-
questions.solution:
• Prilocaine causes less vasodilation than other local anesthetics and is thus used without epinephrine added to the local anesthetic solution.
  • It causes dose related methemoglobinemia which limits its clinical use except in intravenous regional anaesthesia.

questions.text: Arrange the following radiation according to their tissue damaging property from maximum to minimum:

choices.text: γ-rays> X-rays > β – rays > α- rays
α- rays > β – rays > γ-rays > X-rays
α- rays > β – rays > X-rays > γ-rays

questions.solution:
• Tissue damaging property of any radiation from any radioactive material is solely dependent on the ionizing effect. The decreasing order of the ionizing activity is as follows:
  • Alpha > β > X-ray > γ.
  • Alpha particles have approximately four times the mass of a proton or neutron and approximately 8,000 times the mass of a beta particle. Because of the large mass of the alpha particle, it has the highest ionizing power and the greatest ability to damaged tissue.
  • Gamma and X rays, which are electromagnetic, indirectly ionizing radiation. These are indirectly ionizing because they are electrically neutral (as are all electromagnetic radiations) and do not interact with atomic electrons through coulombic forces.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a known case of nephrotic syndrome in the last 4 years on treatment was brought to the pediatric OPD with a chief complaint of difficulty in breathing. There is no history of fever. On examination, the respiratory system was normal except for slightly reduced breath sounds in right infra-axillary region. Paediatrician thinks of pleural effusion. What is the next best modality of investigation to detect pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
• USG Is the preferred investigation (imaging modality) to diagnose a minimal amount of pleural effusions (yellow dotted arrow)

  • An Ipsilateral lateral decubitus x-ray film obtained with the patient lying on their side, effusion side down, can visualise small amounts of fluid layering against the dependent parietal pleura and is preferred x-ray view.
  • Chest radiograph (erect): Both PA and AP erect films are insensitive to small amounts of fluid.
    • Blunting of the costophrenic angle
    • Blunting of the cardiophrenic angle
    • Fluid within the horizontal or oblique fissures

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of increased urinary frequency without burning and nocturia four times each day. He has limited his fluid consumption and caffeine intake in the evening without much benefit. On Prostate examination, the swelling was palpated with a smooth surface, firm, non-tender rubber-like consistency was found. The physician thinks of benign prostate hypertrophy. All are Characteristic features of benign prostate hypertrophy except:
questions.solution:
‘J’ shaped/ ‘fish hook’ proximal ureter is usually seen in IVC compression

Radiological features of BPH:

  • ‘Slit-like’ elongated and compressed urethra
  • Smooth filling defect/ indentation in bladder floor
  • Periurethral and subvesical enlargement is very pronounced may produce rounded defect in floor mimicking Foley’s balloon.
  • Floor of bladder elevated and trigone pushed upwards, with distal ureteral ‘J’ or ‘Fish Hook’ deformity.
  • Trabeculations and distension of bladder
  • Bladder pseudodiverticula and calculi
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter may occur.

On the IVU study, the enlarged prostate gland (P) elevates the bladder floor and causes a J-hooking (fish-hooking) deformity of the distal ureters (arrow).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of increased urinary frequency without burning and nocturia four times each day. He has limited his fluid consumption and caffeine intake in the evening without much benefit. On Prostate examination, the swelling was palpated with a smooth surface, firm, non-tender rubber-like consistency was found. The physician thinks of benign prostate hypertrophy. All are Characteristic features of benign prostate hypertrophy except:
questions.solution:
‘J’ shaped/ ‘fish hook’ proximal ureter is usually seen in IVC compression

Radiological features of BPH:

  • Floor of bladder elevated and trigone pushed upwards, with distal ureteral ‘J’ or ‘Fish Hook’ deformity.
  • Trabeculations and distension of bladder
  • Bladder pseudodiverticula and calculi
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter may occur.

On the IVU study, the enlarged prostate gland (P) elevates the bladder floor and causes a J-hooking (fish-hooking) deformity of the distal ureters (arrow).

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother as her cycles last for 6 to 7 days each month. Her cycles are regular but the mother is worried since she and her older daughter have menses lasting only 3 to 4 days. The physician tells her that this is normal/abnormal as the normal duration of menstrual flow is:
questions.solution:
• Duration of menstruation → 2-7 days
  • Amount of blood loss → 20 ml to 50 mL ( average 35 mL).
  • Nearly 70 percent of total menstrual blood loss occurs in first 2 days.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with regular menstrual cycles, lasting 5 days, coming every 28 days presents for infertility evaluation. Her ovulation scan and husband’s semen analysis are normal. For tubal patency, a Hysterosalpingography should be performed on which day?
questions.solution:
Primary diagnostic steps in the workup of an  infertile couple include :

  • Documentation of ovulation by USG or Mid-luteal phase Serum progesterone
  • Semen analysis
  • Hysterosalpingogram.
    • HSG is performed in the mid-follicular phase (day 8 or 9), in order to evaluate the fallopian tubes and the contour of the uterine cavity. It should not be done while the patient is menstruating actively or after ovulation has occurred and in the premenstrual phase as the patient might be pregnant.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with complains of dysmenorrhea. She states that her pain starts few days before onset of periods and subsides by day 3. Ultrasound reveals an ovarian cyst with ground glass appearance. She was started on a drug, which after use for 6 months caused an increase in hepatic enzyme and adverse lipid profile. Which is the most probable drug used?
questions.solution:
• This patient has presented with congestive type dysmenorrhea and an ovarian cyst with ground glass appearance suggestive of endometriosis.
  • Out of the mentioned drugs, only OCP and GnRH analogues are used for endometriosis.
  • Rifampicin and methotrexate cause hepatotoxicity, but are not used for endometriosis
  • OC pills (progesterone component) are associated with an increase in LDL and decrease in HDL cholesterol, but estrogens have the opposite effect. Cholestasis and cholestatic jaundice are occasional side effects of OC pills.
  • GnRh analogues: hypoestrogenic side effects: hot flashes, osteoporosis, headache
  • Drugs used for medical management of endometriosis are:
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Mirena: LNG IUCD
  • Progesterones: Dienogest, Medroxyprogesterone, dydrogesterone
  • Androgens: danazol
  • GnRH analogues
  • Mifepristone

questions.text: A gynecological surgeon performs a hysterectomy for a large uterine fibroid. It was a difficult surgery as there were pelvic adhesions and the fibroid was large, distorting normal pelvic anatomy. As the patient is shifted for post-operative care, the surgeon instructs his resident to watch for expected complications. All of these are relevant instructions, EXCEPT?

choices.text: Watch for decreased urine output, due to bladder or ureteric injury
Watch for frequency and incontinence of urine after catheter removal, due to bladder hypertonia
Watch for tachycardia/ hypotension/ falling hemoglobin, due to internal hemorrhage
Watch for abdominal distension/ vomiting, due to bowel injury

questions.solution:
Complications of Hysterectomy

Risk of complications is higher in patients with difficult surgery and associated complications and co-morbidities.

  • Hemorrhage: bleeding in drain, abdominal distension, tachycardia, hypotension, fall in hemoglobin
  • Wound Infection: fever, discharge from incision
  • Cuff Cellulitis: pain, fever discharge
  • Bladder Hypotonia (NOT hypertonia): urinary retention
  • Stress urinary incontinence: involuntary leak
  • Prolapse of vault: late complication, mass descending from vagina
  • Cuff dehiscence: discharge pv
  • Uretric/ Bladder: abdominal distension, decreased urine output, fluid from abdominal drain
  • Bowel injury: abdominal distension, vomiting, constipation

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman, postmenopausal, presents with itchy vulvar lesions. On examination, the lesions are pinkish, with ulcerations with oozing and bleed to touch. A biopsy done shows adenocarcinoma, with the glandular formation of large cells with pale vacuolated cytoplasm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Extra Mammary Paget’s disease is associated with Vulva cancer

  • Occurs in a postmenopausal woman as a sharply demarcated and slightly elevated pink- white indurated or eczematous lesion
  • Adenocarcinomas of the vulva usually occur in a Bartholin gland or occur in association with Paget disease.
  • The treatment is local excision or vulvectomy if no underlying lesion is detected.
  • With underlying lesion, treatment is as of invasive cancer.
  • Radiotherapy is employed for women unfit for surgery but prolonged follow-up for recurrence is obligatory. Local and systemic 5FU and bleomycin is also tried.

Premalignant lesions of vulva

  • VIN: vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia
  • Lichen sclerosis
  • Pagets disease

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes for treatment of hirsutism. She is obese and has facial acne and hirsutism on her face. Serum LH level is 32 mIU/mL and FSH is 9 mIU/mL. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are mildly elevated, serum DHEAS is normal. The patient not wishing to conceive at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has PCOS, diagnosed by

  • Clinical picture- Obese, Facial acne and Hirsutism
  • Abnormally High LH-to-FSH ratio, and increased androgens but Normal DHEAS (excludes Adrenal sources of Hyperandrogenism)

To treat Hirsutism associated with PCOS:-

  • OC pills suppress hair growth, act by directly suppressing ovarian steroid production and increasing hepatic binding globulin production, which binds circulating hormone and lowers the concentrations of metabolically active (free unbound) androgen.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents for a routine cervical cancer screen. Which of the following is used to take a cervical smear:
questions.solution:
Ayre’s spatula

  • Used to take cervical smear (Pap smear)
  • It is a wooden spatula with U-shaped openings on one side and a flat surface on another.
  • Takes sample from squamocolumnar junction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old asymptomatic woman on a routine abdominal ultrasound done as a part of a health check-up shows a benign uterine tumor. Which of the following is the most likely lesion?
questions.solution:
Fibroid

  • Most common benign uterine tumor
  • Most common benign pelvic tumor in females

Types

  • Intramural (75%)
  • Subserous (15%)
  • Submucous (5%)

questions.text:
The following is a laparoscopic image of right upper quadrant in a patient of PID. All are true regarding the given image except?



.

choices.text: May lead to right upper quadrant pain
Pain may refer to the shoulder or upper arm
Most commonly associated with tubercular salpingitis

questions.solution:
Fitz-Hugh–Curtis syndrome: -

  • A woman with PID complains of Acute right-sided upper abdominal pain simulating Cholecystitis.
  • This is due to a fibrous band extending from the Right adnexa to the undersurface of the Liver in PID caused by Gonococcal and Chlamydial infection.
  • Violin string’ like adhesions in the pelvis and around the liver suggests Chlamydial infection.

questions.text: A 38-years old patient who had a total abdominal hysterectomy presents 2 months postop complaining of leakage of urine from the vagina. On examination, no fistula can be identified. Dilute methylene blue (100mL) is injected into the bladder through a Foley catheter and a tampon is placed in the vagina. The patient is asked to walk for about 15 minutes, after which the patient is found to be wet, but there is no blue stain anywhere on the tampon. Which of the following is true:-

choices.text: 100mL was probably not enough methylene blue, and the test should be repeated with a higher volume
The patient probably has stress incontinence not a fistula
The patient probably has a ureterovaginal fistula
The patient most likely has small apical vesicovaginal fistula that was too small to leak the dye in 15 minutes

questions.solution:
Methylene blue Swab Test-

  • A Catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra,
  • The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile swabs,
  • 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder through the catheter
    • If there is a VVF present, the methylene blue dye stains the uppermost swab
    • If the lowermost swab gets stained, the leak is from the urethra--> urethrovaginal fistula
    • If the swabs do not take up the stain, but get wet with urine, the leak is from the ureter-->ureterovaginal fistula

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea, on examination has a blind vaginal pouch with absence of uterus. Investigation to be done is
questions.solution:
• The patient with primary amenorrhea, here is phenotypic female with absent vagina and uterus
  • 3 possibilities here
    • Mullerian agenesis: 46 XX
    • Testicular feminization: 46 XY
    • Swyer syndrome: 46 XY

A Karyotyping will be the best to differentiate between the three.

questions.text: A young woman presented with infertility. Hysterosalpingogram shows beaded fallopian tubes with clubbing of the ampullary end. The most likely diagnosis is:-
questions.solution:
Genital tuberculosis is a known cause of infertility.

HSG features of Genital TB

  • Lead pipe appearance
  • Beaded tubes and variation in the filling
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of Hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • A jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother as she has started to have cyclical vaginal bleeding since 3 months. She also has started showing signs of breast development and growth of pubic and axillary hair. On laboratory testing her LH and FSH are found to be in the range similar to reproductive age women. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy in this case?
questions.solution:
• This girl has presented with the onset of menarche along with other signs of puberty such as breast development, pubic and axillary hair growth. These along with raised LH and FSH are suggestive of central precocious puberty.
  • Most effective treatment for central precocious puberty is the use of a Long-acting GnRH agonist, such as leuprolide and others.
    • These drugs act by down regulating pituitary gonadotropes, eventually decreasing the secretion of FSH and LH, which are inappropriately stimulating the ovaries.
    • As a result of this induced hypogonadotropic state, ovarian hormones (estrogens, progestins, and androgens) are suppressed back to pre-pubertal levels, and precocious pubertal development stops or regresses.
    • During the first 1 or 2 weeks of therapy, there is a flare-up effect of increased gonadotropins and sex steroids-a predicted side effect of these medications.
    • At the time of expected puberty, the GnRH analogue is discontinued and the pubertal sequence resumes.

questions.text: A gynecologist while performing a caesarean section asks for this instrument after dissecting the bladder away from the uterus. Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
Doyen’s Retractor

  • Used for retraction of the abdominal wall
  • Used for retraction of the bladder during CS and hysterectomy
  • Broad retracting surface achieves good retraction
  • Decreases blood loss by compression

Indications

  • Caesarean Section
  • Laparotomy
  • TAH
  • Prolapse repair
  • Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) repair surgeries

questions.text: A woman presents for contraceptive counselling. She is 32 years old and has no contraindications for use of Oral contraceptive pills. The doctor tells her that the failure rate of these pills is less than 1 per HWY (Hundred Woman Years). This failure rate is calculated as?

choices.text: Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies
Total accidental pregnancies × 100 / Number of women Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy
Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy

questions.solution:
• The use-effectiveness of contraceptive method is expressed as Pearl rate & life table technique.
  • Pearl rate or pearl index was introduced by Raymond Pearl in 1932.
  • The rate is expressed as pregnancy rate per 100 women-years (HWY) & calculated as:
    • Pregnancy rate per HWY = Total accidental pregnancies × 1200/ Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive; 1200 is the number of months in 100 years

questions.text: A multiparous woman after delivery of the placenta starts to bleed heavily. On examination, the cervix and vaginal wall are healthy but the uterus is large and flabby. All of the following drugs can be used for the management, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
This is a case of postpartum hemorrhage due to an atonic uterus.

Drugs used for the management of PPH:

  • Oxytocin- DOC for prevention as well as treatment of PPH
  • Methyl Ergometrine
  • Misoprostol
  • Carboprost
  • Recombinant VII
  • Fibrinogen
