questions.text: Occurrence of pregnancy is characterized by persistence of corpus luteum which serves to produce the most important pregnancy hormone, progesterone, till the placenta is formed and is fully functional. Placenta takes over function of corpus luteum for production of hormone at:
questions.solution:
• Placenta starts making estrogen, progesterone after 6 weeks
  • Luteo-placental shift occurs from 6-9 weeks, this means that the placenta starts to take over the function of corpus luteum of hormone production such that by 8-9 weeks; most of estrogen and progesterone in maternal circulation is placental in origin.
  • The function of the corpus luteum begins to decline after 8 weeks of pregnancy, but it persists throughout pregnancy.

questions.text: An ultrasound done in a multigravida at 30 weeks gestation shows abnormal insertion of the cord. The radiologist suspects a vasa previa. Follow up investigation of choice for diagnosis of vasa previa is:
questions.solution:
• Vasa Previa: Color Doppler is the investigation of choice.
  • A transabdominal color Doppler sonography which shows 'flow' in vessels overlying the internal cervical os.
  • A Transvaginal ultrasound with color Doppler is an even better method to demonstrate this.
  • The APT test is a biochemical test done to differentiate maternal and fetal blood when a pregnant woman presents with a vaginal bleeding episode.
  • Most vaginal bleeding in antepartum hemorrhage are due to abruption and Placenta previa.
  • Placental abruption (32 percent), Previa (21 percent), and Cervical bleeding (6.6 percent) were the most frequent causes. However, when these are not confirmed, then to suspect fetal bleeding due to Vasa Previa, an APT test is done.
  • Here, the vaginal blood is mixed with NaOH, and if the hemoglobin gets denatured (Colorless) then its maternal blood.
  • A positive APT test would indicate that blood is of fetal origin.
  • A negative test indicates that the blood is of maternal origin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestational age has a blood pressure reading of 150/100 mm Hg obtained during a routine visit. Her baseline blood pressure during the pregnancy was 120/70 mm Hg. The patient denies any headache, visual changes, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Her repeat BP is 160/90 mm Hg, and urinalysis is negative for protein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg or greater on at least two separate occasions that are 6 h or more apart.
  • Gestational hypertension: - Maternal blood pressure reaches 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks and proteinuria is not present.
  • Preeclampsia- blood pressure increases to 140/90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).
  • Eclampsia- is present when women with preeclampsia develop seizures.
  • Chronic hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 mm Hg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: A woman at 29 years of age, primigravida presents to ANC clinic for routine evaluation. Her HbA1c done in the first trimester was normal and she does not have a history of diabetes. Her Glucose tolerance test done now at 24 weeks, shows a 2-hour value of 180 mg/dL. Which of the following complications is usually NOT expected in such a case?
questions.solution:
Polyhydramnios is a complication of diabetes, not Oligohydramnios.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)

  • Defined as glucose intolerance first recognized during pregnancy.
  • In this patient overt diabetes is ruled out as the patient has normal HbA1c. OGTT is a screening test for GDM.
  • Normal values are 92/180/153 (fasting/ 1 hour after 75gm glucose/ 2 hour after glucose load).
  • The patient in question has deranged values diagnostic of GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus).
  • Overt diabetes is diagnosed with a 2-hour glucose value>200 mg/dL.

Complications of gestational Diabetes/ overt diabetes:

  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Unexplained fetal demise
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Malformation
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Cardiomyopathy: hypertrophic, affects interventricular septum
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Macrosomia: shoulder dystocia, instrumental or operative delivery, birth canal lacerations
  • Respiratory distress syndrome

However, long-standing and poorly controlled type 1 diabetes represents a wide spectrum of clinical conditions and may in the worst cases present with IUGR and oligohydramnios. But the data on IUGR and oligohydramnios in type 1 diabetic pregnancy is limited.

His growth was normal until the first two years of his life and then the growth retarded, his eyes were sunken brittle nails & hair. For a 3-year-old child, the body weight should be how many times the birth weight?

questions.text: A child is able to draw and copy cross & square at the age of 4. His mother plays with him and makes a triangle and the child tries to copy that and he is successfully able to do it. At what age is he able to perform this?
questions.solution: A child is able to draw a triangle by the age of- 5 years

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was being examined in the OPD by the JR when he notices that the child's development is not normal. He asks the interns present there to calculate his DQ, which came out to be equal to that of a child half his age. Which of the following milestones this child has achieved according to his DQ?
questions.solution:
DQ = Developmental age x 100/actual age

The 6-year-old child has a DQ of 50, so his developmental age is 3 years. So he can do milestones corresponding to 3 years only.

  • Speaks short sentences - at 2 years (child can speak 2-word sentences at 2 years and 3-word sentences at 3 years)
  • Ride a tricycle- at 3 yrs
  • Name 2 colors - At 3 years
  • Name 5 colors - At 5 years
  • Copy a triangle- at 5 years
  • Since option 2 is the only milestone the child has reached, the answer is option 2.

questions.text: 16 years old boy, whenever he gets out to play with the other boys of his age he is bullied and the child has become anxious about being bullied. He then visits his uncle who is a pediatrician and explains to him. His uncle tells him about the delayed development of puberty. He asks what is the first visible sign of puberty?
questions.solution: In boys- the first visible sign of puberty is testicular enlargement. While in girls, the first sign of puberty is thelarche or breast development.

questions.text: A 28 yrs old primigravida at 32 weeks started experiencing pain and was taken to the gynae emergency. On examination by the first-year JR on duty, it was found that she had true labor pain, delivery was vacuum-assisted, and the neonate was kept in NICU for LBW & elevated bilirubin levels. The nurse on duty in NICU observes an edematous swelling over the occiput and informs the doctor. Which statement is incorrect regarding the swelling?

choices.text: It is a soft & boggy swelling
It can predispose to prolonged jaundice
Vacuum-assisted delivery is one of the common underlying causes

questions.solution:
Cephalhematoma predisposes to neonatal jaundice & not caput succedaneum.

No.

Cephalhematoma

Caput succedaneum

1.

Subperiosteal hemorrhage involving cranial bones

Due to edema in the layers of the scalp

2.

Do not cross sutures

Can cross sutures

3.

Takes 5-7 weeks to disappear

Disappears by 48-72 hours

4.

Predisposes to neonatal jaundice

Does not predispose to neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A 28 yrs old primigravida gave birth to a 34 weeks premature baby girl. He was kept in the neonatal ICU for further intervention and after the mother became ambulatory she was told to breastfeed her baby as soon as possible. Until what time is she told to only breastfeed her and no water or any other formula feed?
questions.solution:
• Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended till the age of 6 months; thereafter 'complimentary feeding' is introduced.
  • In exclusive breastfeeding only breast milk is given to the child; nothing other than breast milk except vitamin drops if indicated.

questions.text: A male child whose age is 10 yrs, his weight is now 20 kg's as he has lost 4kg's in last one week. He is admitted to the hospital after he was diagnosed as suffering from gastroenteritis. He had several episodes of diarrhea and vomiting and is now severely dehydrated. He is now on fluid replenishment therapy. Daily maintenance fluid for this child will be?
questions.solution:
Fluid requirement in this child weighing 24 kg is: 1580 mL.

  • For first 10 kgs: 100ml/kg
  • For next 10 kgs: 50ml/kg
  • For each kg above 20kgs: 20 ml/kg

So,

(1–10 kg) 100 x 10 = 1000 mL

(11–20 kg) 50 x 10 = 500 mL;

For next 4 kg (21–24 kg) 20 x 4= 80 mL

questions.text: A primigravida 36 yrs old in her second trimester of pregnancy comes to the clinic for her antenatal visit and was advised to undergo a triple test by her gynaecologist. It is used for screening for Down syndrome in the 2nd trimester. The test includes all the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Triple test:

  • Used for screening of Down syndrome in 2nd trimester
  • It includes:
    • AFP (α-fetoprotein)
    • β-HCG (β-human chorionic gonadotropin)
    • Unconjugated estriol
  • Detection rate is 67%

Quadruple test:

  • Triple test + Inhibin A
  • It is also used as screening test for Down syndrome in 2nd trimester
  • Detection rate is 77%

questions.text: In the Anatomy practical exam, your professor questioned that the part of the following bone marked with an arrow develops from?
questions.solution:
• Stapes develops from the dorsal end of the Reichert's cartilage (2nd branchial arch), however the medial surface of stapes footplate and its Annular ligament are derived from otic capsule (lamina stapedialis), which develops in the mesoderm surrounding the membranous labyrinth.
  • Formation of footplate:
  • The classical theory presumes that footplate has 2 origins: The Tympanic side derived from the stapedial ring and the Vestibular side derived from the lamina stapedialis of the otic capsule.
  • The medial border of stapedial ring comes in contact with a facing depression in the lateral wall of otic capsule. This depression called the lamina stapedialis is the future oval window and it fuses with the medial border of the stapedial ring to form the stapes footplate

questions.text: 65 years old uncontrolled diabetes patient came to your clinic with a complaint of otalgia, greenish discharge from the ear. Further examination helps you to diagnose the case as malignant otitis externa. Which of the following dehiscence in the external auditory canal leads to the spread of infection in this case?
questions.solution:
• Malignant external otitis (MEO) is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone.
  • The causative organism is usually Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in immune deficiency patients.
  • The infection begins as external otitis that progresses into osteomyelitis of the temporal bone (Lateral Skull base osteomyelitis).
  • Spread of the disease outside the external auditory canal occurs through the fissures of Santorini (two vertical fissures in the anterior portion of the cartilage of the external auditory meatus, filled by fibrous tissue) and the osseocartilaginous junction.
  • Notch of Rivinus-It is a defect in the upper tympanic part of the temporal bone, filled by the upper portion of the tympanic membrane.
  • Petro-tympanic fissure-It is a fissure in the temporal bone that runs from the temporomandibular joint to the tympanic cavity.
  • Foramen of Huschke-It represents a developmental defect in the anteroinferior aspect of the bony external auditory meatus.

questions.text: 62-year-old judge became aware of the subtle weakness of his left lower face that he first noted while shaving. Two months later, he noted that he could no longer close his left eyelid fully and he was having increasing weakness of the remainder of his left face. Which of the following is a narrowest segment of the nerve in the ear involved here?
questions.solution:
Labyrinthine segment (3.0 mm)

  • From fundus of meatus to geniculate ganglion where nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a “genu.”
  • Nerve in labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter (0.61–0.68 mm) and bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest.
  • Thus, edema or inflammation can easily compress nerve and cause paralysis.
  • This is also the shortest segment of the nerve.

questions.text: Your ENT professor was lecturing about inner ear. You and your friends are on the last bench and playing clash of clans. The professor caught you and questioned you: where Cristae are seen?
questions.solution:
• Cristae are located in the ampullated ends of the three semicircular canals.
  • These receptors respond to angular acceleration

questions.text: You are examining a patient in ENT OPD. Patient gives the typical history of office headache and on examination, area of localized tenderness noted over the eyebrow. which of the following is the best X-ray view for evaluating for the above condition?
questions.solution:
• Caldwell view is the occipito- frontal view (nose-forehead position). The frontal sinuses are best seen in this view.
  • Water’s with open mouth is the occipito-mental view. All the four sinuses the maxillary, frontal, ethmoid (anterior) and sphenoid sinuses are clearly visible.
  • Schuller’s view is lateral oblique view of mastoid.
  • Towne’s view is the antero-posterior view to see both the petrous pyramids and posterior cranial fossa.

questions.text: You are a 1st year ENT resident and presenting a case about diseases of nasal septum. Your senior doctor questioned you that "Incidence of septal perforation is less common in septoplasty than in submucous resection of nasal septum because?"

choices.text: Incidence of septal hematoma is less common in septoplasty
Dissection of the septum is made on one side
Septal cartilage is remodelled and left in place

questions.solution:
• In septoplasty, muco-perichondrium is raised only on one side compared to SMR where it is raised on both sides of nasal septum
  • Septoplasty is a conservative surgery whereas SMR is radical surgery
  • Only deviated part of bone and cartilage is removed in septoplasty

questions.text: A carpenter came to the ENT OPD with complaints of swelling in the left cheek and frequent epistaxis. On examination, loss of sensation of the left cheek noted with nasal mass. Which of the following describes the prognosis of the mass in relation to the location?

choices.text: Medial canthus to the angle of mandible
Lateral canthus to the angle of mandible
Medial canthus to the mastoid process
Lateral canthus to the mastoid process

questions.solution:
OHNGREN'S LINE

  • An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible
  • The line defines a plane orthogonal to a sagittal plane that divides the maxillary sinus into:
  • Anteroinferior part (Infrastructure): Good prognosis
  • Posterosuperior part (Suprastructure): Bad Prognosis

questions.text: 10 years old boy came to ENT OPD with complaints of B/L serous otitis media. Patient's mother gives the history of recurrent upper respiratory infection. On further inspection, patient presented with below depicted facial features. which of the following is not a complication of the procedure done for this condition?
questions.solution:
Normal physiological growth pattern

  • 3-5 years age- growth starts
  • 5-7 years age- maximum size
  • >7 years age- growth size decreases

Clinical features

  • B/L nasal obstruction- results in mouth breathing-high arched palate
  • Adenoid facies-
    • Elongated face, pinched nose
    • Overcrowding of anterior teeth
  • B/L serous otitis media
  • B/L conductive hearing loss
  • Recurrent upper respiratory infection
  • Obstructive sleep apnea

Treatment

Adenoidectomy

  • Adenoids lead to Hyponasal speech (Rhinolalia Clausa) but not Post adenoidectomy
  • COMPLICATIONS OF ADENOIDECTOMY:
  • Hemorrhage- Primary, Secondary & Reactionary
  • Injury to Eustachian tube opening
  • Injury to pharyngeal musculature & vertebrae
  • Grisel syndrome - Atlantoaxial subluxation
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis

questions.text: A female baby was brought to your OPD for a general check-up. On examination, the baby was able to follow the bell of the stethoscope with her eyes when shown in front of her. The probable age of the child would be:
questions.solution:
VISUAL DEVELOPMENT

Age

Visual Development Milestone

At Birth

Fixation at light held 8-10 inches away, momentarily

6 - 8 weeks

Fixation of light and objects more steady

3 months

Follows moving objects

5 - 6 months

Depth perception, colour vision and eye-body coordination

questions.text: Meibomian glands are the tiny oil glands that line the margin of the eyelids (the edges which touch when the eyelids are closed). These glands secrete oil which coats the surface of our eyes and keeps the water component of our tears from evaporating (drying out). Which of the following is not true about this gland?

choices.text: More in upper lid than in lower lid

questions.solution:
Meibomian glands open in eyelid margins

Meibomian glands

  • Arranged vertically
  • More in upper lid than in lower lid
  • Modified sebaceous glands
  • Open in eyelid margins
  • Constitute the oily layer of tear film
  • Internal Hordeolum is the infection of meibomian gland

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with Alport's syndrome was scheduled for femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) because of the anterior lenticonus in the left eye of the patient. The laser that is used in this procedure is of wavelength?
questions.solution:
• Femtosecond laser (1053 nm) is the new paradigm in the Ophthalmology. Its uses are:
  • Femtosecond laser assisted cataract surgery (FLACS)
  • Refractive surgery - Femto LASIK, SMILE
  • Keratoplasty - Femto-assisted Penetrating and Lamellar Keratoplasty
  • Intracorneal ring segments for keratoconus (INTACS)
  • Nd:YAG laser has a wavelength of 1064 nm
  • Frequency doubled Nd:YAG has wavelength of 532
  • Argon Fluoride laser has a wavelength of 193 nm

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented to your clinic with a complaint of a red, watery and painful left eye for 2 days. From the given history, you are suspecting Acute iritis in this patient. If you do an examination of the eye, the pupil would be:
questions.solution:
• In acute iritis (inflammation of iris) iris is irritated and the pupil constricts due to the stimulus of irritation
  • A vertically oval, mid-dilated, non reacting pupil is seen in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient who was on topical antiglaucoma drug therapy for several months presented with the features shown in the given image. The likely antiglaucoma drug responsible for this adverse effect is:
questions.solution:
Side effects of Prostaglandin Analogues (Latanoprost, Travoprost, Bimatoprost, Tafluprost)

  • Ocular
    • Conjunctival hyperemia
    • Eyelash lengthening
    • Peri-ocular skin hyperpigmentation - may be reversible
    • Irreversible iris hyperpigmentation - due to increase in number of pigment granules in the superficial stroma of the iris (not the pigment cells) - more common in patients with light coloured iris, hence can produce heterochromia iridis
    • Peri-ocular atrophy
    • Cystoid macular edema especially when used in post-operative patients - hence avoided in patients with postoperative glaucoma/IOP spikes
    • Anterior uveitis - hence avoided in patients with inflammatory glaucoma
    • Promotion of herpetic keratitis
  • Systemic
    • Headache, precipitation of migraine
    • Malaise, Myalgia, Skin Rash, mild upper respiratory tract symptoms

questions.text: 42-year-old male presents with dimness of near vision and cannot read the newspaper print clearly. On examination, the media was clear in both the eyes and no fundus abnormality was seen. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
PRESBYOPIA

  • There is a decline in the accommodative power of the crystalline lens with age. Infants have a 14D accommodation and falls to 4D at 45 years of age and 1D at 60 years of age. This decline in the accommodative power is called PRESBYOPIA for which near add (convex glasses) is prescribed to individual.

Surgical Modalities to correct Presbyopia:

  • Multifocal IOL
  • Crystalens
  • Presbyopic LASIK

questions.text: 7-year-old male child present with normal vision 6/6 in right eye & hand movement perception close to the face in left eye. On fundoscopy, his right eye was normal & left eye showed retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates and telangiectatic vessels. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
All of the options provided can cause retinal detachment however the associated clinical features are different

COATS DISEASE

FAMILIAL EXUDATIVE VITREORETINOPATHY (FEVR)
  • Cause of Idiopathic retinal telangectasia
  • 1st decade of life
  • 75% males involved
  • 95% unilateral disease
  • Variable prognosis - depends on severity at presentation
  • Younger age of onset, more severe presentation
  • Present with unilateral vision loss, strabismus, leukcoria
  • Clinical findings
    • Classical - retinal telangectasia and focal fusiform arteriolar aneurysms
    • Intra- and sub-retinal exudates commonly involving the macula
      • Exudative Retinal Detachment
  • Management
    • Observation - in mild disease without visual symptoms or in patients without potential for visual recovery
    • Laser ablation of leakage points causing exudation
    • Intravireal Anti-VEGF therapy
    • Cryotherapy as an alternative to laser ablation
    • Vitreoretinal surgery if tractional fibrosis or total retinal detachment occurs
  • Slowly progressive failure of vascularization of the temporal retinal periphery similar to ROP
  • AD inheritance with high penetrance and variable expressivity
  • Usually presents in childhood
  • Poor prognosis due to early aggressive onset
  • Associated with high myopia
  • Presents with
    • Peripheral avascularity with abrupt termination of retinal vessels temporally
    • Peripheral vascular tortuosity and telangectasia which can progress to preretinal fibrovascular proliferation with or without subretinal exudation
    • Tractional and or Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachement
  • Management
    • Requires lifelong monitoring
    • Laser ablation of avascular retina
    • Vitreoretinal surgery for Retinal detachment
    • Relatives need to be screened

RETINOBLASTOMA

  • Neural retinal tumour - composed of immature retinoblasts with variable differentiation
  • Most common primary intra-ocular malignancy of childhood
  • Growth may be endophytic or exophytic or diffusely spreading
  • Hallmark is intra-ocular calcification
  • Retinal detachment can occur due to exudation near the underlying tumour or due to neovascularization and tractional retinal detachment

RETINOPATHY OF PREMATURITY

  • Seen in premature low birth weight infants including additional risk factors such as high ambient oxygen concentrations, prolonged hospitalization, perinatal sepsis, etc
  • As expected, this would be seen in infancy and not in young children and is identified based on screening
  • Retinal detachment can occur in patients in due progress of ROP

questions.text: A 30-year-old women presented with history of nyctalopia and constriction of visual field of the left eye. On fundus examination, a pale optic disc, narrowed arterioles and extensive proliferations of the pigment epithelium in form of bone spicules in the periphery could be seen. The doctor made the diagnosis of retinitis pigmentosa. Which of the following is not associated with Retinitis pigmentosa ?
questions.solution:
• Remember RP associations by mnemonic LUCHR.
  • Lawrence-Moon-Beidel Syndrome
  • Usher Syndrome
  • Cockayne Syndrome
  • Hallgren Syndrome
  • Refsum Syndrome
  • Other associations: NARP, Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Retinitis Pigmentosa is not associated with Hallervorden Spatz Syndrome

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented in altered sensorium with complaints of melena and abdominal distension. On abdominal examination shifting dullness is present. Which of the following nail finding is seen in the given condition?
questions.solution:
• Terry's nails in cirrhosis
  • Twenty-nail dystrophy - Can be present on its own or be associated with other skin conditions such as Lichen planus, eczema, psoriasis and alopecia areata
  • Koilonychia is seen in iron deficiency anemia
  • Onycholysis is seen in psoriasis, onychomycosis, trauma, with wet work
  • Pterygium of nail is seen in Lichen Planus

questions.text: A newborn had a pinkish-blue lesion over the upper eyelid. There was no lid edema or eye involvement, increase in size and the lesion regressed spontaneously at about one year of age. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Salmon Patch (Nevus Simplex)
  • Small, pale, pink, ill-defined, vascular macules on the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area
  • Present as localized vascular ectasia and may become more visible during crying or changes in environmental temperature.
  • Lesions on the face fade and disappear completely, but on the posterior neck and occipital areas often persist.
  • Symmetric lesions on both eyelids & both sides of the midline.

  • Port-wine stains are often larger, unilateral, permanent & usually end along the midline.
  • Capillary Hemangioma -presents in first month of life and progressively increases in size for 8-9 months and then regresses spontaneously leaving behind fibrocollagenous remnant.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with a hypopigmented patch over the left forearm measuring 5 centimeters for the past one month. HPE showed skin with the subepidermal region showing numerous epithelioid granulomas surrounded by lymphocytes. A diagnosis of Hansen's disease is made. The Earliest sensation to be lost in Hansen's disease is: -
questions.solution:
• First sensation to be lost in leprosy: Temp (cold > hot)
  • Patients cannot sense extremes of hot or cold. The next sensation lost is touch (light pressure), followed by pain and finally deep pressure.
  • MC cranial nerve involved: Facial
  • MC peripheral nerve involved: Ulnar > Posterior Tibial

questions.text: A female with genital warts is being treated in the outpatient department. The doctor teaches her about measures that may prevent recurrences and emphasizes the need for prompt treatment if complications arise. Genital warts increase the risk of:
questions.solution:
• A female with genital warts is at increased risk for cervical cancer.
  • HPV is the primary neoplastic-initiating event in the vast majority of women with invasive cervical cancer.
  • HPV -16 and -18 are the types most frequently associated with high-grade dysplasia.
